choices.text: No change is ESR
Confirms recovery from TB
ESR is raised because of increased RBC aggregate
ESR is raised due to decreased RBC size

questions.text: ESR is a very critical investigation is the diagnosis of TB. Which of the following is true about ESR in TB?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ESR is raised because of increased RBC aggre­gate

 

  • ESR is a nonspecific test which is used as an indicator of active disease.
  • It increases in some disease states due to increase in plasma fibrinogen, immunoglobulins and other acute phase reactants.
  • In addition, change in red cell shape and number affect ESR.
  • So, in a patient with TB, ESR will increase due to aggregation of red cells called rouleaux whose formation is facilitated by fibrinogen. Since, it is nonspecific; it cannot confirm recovery from TB.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with a history of Schizophrenia is being seen in the clinic for a medication review. She has been stable on her current medication but is concerned about her recent weight gain of 15 pounds over the past 6 months. She is conscious about her weight and does not want any medication that might exacerbate this issue. She inquires about potential antipsychotic medications that might be less likely to cause weight gain. Which of the following antipsychotics would be the best recommendation for this patient if considering the potential for weight gain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aripiprazole

 

  • Aripiprazole is known for having a lower risk of causing weight gain compared to other antipsychotics.
  • In patients who are concerned about weight gain or metabolic side effects, aripiprazole is often considered a good choice due to its more favorable metabolic profile.
  • It is effective in managing symptoms of schizophrenia while minimizing the risk of significant weight gain and other metabolic disturbances.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Olanzapine. Associated with significant weight gain, as well as other metabolic side effects.

 

Option C. Quetiapine. Can cause moderate weight gain, though not as much as olanzapine.

 

Option D. Risperidone. This can also lead to weight gain, but generally less than olanzapine and quetiapine.

 

Educational objective:

 

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY OF ANTIPSYCHOTIC-INDUCED WEIGHT GAIN

 

 

Aripiprazole and ziprasidone are two antipsychotics with a relatively lower risk of weight gain compared to others. Olanzapine and clozapine are most associated with weight gain.

 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No. 123

choices.text: Combination oral contraceptives
Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient presents with complaints of menorrhagia which has been increasing. She has no other medical problems. 3D USG reveals the findings as shown below. All EXCEPT which of the following are choices for medical treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNGIUS)

 

  • The image is a 3D USG image of a large submucosal fibroid.
  • This can be managed medically by:
    • NSAIDs
    • Antifibrinolytics
    • Combined OCPS
    • Injectable Progesterones (DMPA)
    • SPRMs (ulipristal, mifepristone)
    • GnRH agonists
    • LNG-IUS (Mirena)
  • However, Mirena, is contra-indicated when there is significant distortion of the endometrial cavity which is seen in a submucosal fibroid; hence, an LNG-IUS should not be given to this woman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intra-uterine devices like Mirena (LNG-IUS) are contra-indicated in a uterus with distorted anatomy like Mullerian anomalies or the presence of a large submucosal fibroid or sometimes intra-mural fibroids that distort the cavity

 

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, page no. 208

choices.text: For intubation in an anticipated difficult airway
Guide placement of double lumen tube
Suction of blood from the airways
All of the above

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown below in the picture.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option A. For intubation in an anticipated difficult airway: A flexible fiber optic bronchoscope is often used to navigate and visualize the airway in cases where difficult intubation is anticipated, such as with abnormal airway anatomy.

 

Option B. Guide placement of double lumen tube: In thoracic surgery requiring lung isolation, a double-lumen endotracheal tube is used, and a fiber optic bronchoscope is often employed to confirm proper placement and position of the tube.

 

Option C. Suction of blood from the airways: While primarily used for visualization, a bronchoscope can also assist in the suctioning of blood or secretions from the airway when necessary.

 

Option D. All of the above: Since the bronchoscope can be used for all the above-mentioned purposes, this option is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective for medical students is to identify a flexible fibre optic bronchoscope and understand its multifunctional use in airway management, including aiding difficult intubations, guiding the placement of double-lumen tubes, and clearing the airways of obstructions such as blood or secretions.

choices.text: Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

questions.text: During a routine examination of the larynx, a 35-year-old professional singer reports difficulty in maintaining pitch during performances. The otolaryngologist decides to evaluate the function of the muscles involved in the modulation of voice and tension of the vocal cords. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for the tension and modulation of the pitch of the vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid muscle

 

  • Given the singer's difficulty with maintaining pitch, the cricothyroid muscle's role in adjusting the tension of the vocal cords is most relevant to the clinical scenario.

 

 

  • The cricothyroid muscle is the correct answer.
  • It functions as a tensor of the vocal cords and is critical in the modulation of voice and pitch.
  • When the cricothyroid muscle contracts, it tilts the thyroid cartilage, increasing the tension on the vocal cords and raising the pitch of the voice.
  • This action is key for a singer's performance.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The aryepiglottic muscle is involved in closing the inlet of the larynx, not directly in the modulation of voice or tension of the vocal cords. Therefore, while important for protective reflexes such as swallowing, it would not be the primary muscle involved in the issue the singer is facing.

 

Option B. The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is one of the adductors of the vocal cords, bringing them together for phonation. However, it is not the primary muscle responsible for the tension and pitch modulation of the vocal cords.

 

Option D. The thyroarytenoid muscle, including the muscle vocalis, acts as a relaxor of the vocal cords. It is involved in shortening and relaxing the vocal cords, which lowers the pitch. While this muscle plays a role in modulating the voice, it is not responsible for increasing tension to modulate pitch upwards, which is the singer's concern.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

  • A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

 

  • Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day.
  • Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools.
  • If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.
  • Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents.
  • Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.
  • Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea.
  • Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications.
  • Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is an H1-receptor antagonist that also has serotonin receptor antagonistic property on the appetite center. This drug has the ability to stimulate appetite?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cyproheptadine

 

  • Most of the first-generation antihistaminic agents have additional effects unrelated to their ability to block H1receptors.
  • These effects reflect binding of the H1-receptor antagonists to cholinergic, adrenergic, or serotonin receptors.
  • For example, cyproheptadine also acts as a serotonin antagonist on the appetite center and is sometimes used off label as an appetite stimulant.

questions.text: You are a pediatric resident working in a tertiary care hospital. A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her worried parents due to enlarged abdomen. On physical examination, you notice hepatomegaly. Concerned about a possible metabolic disorder, you decide to investigate further. Laboratory investigations revealed abnormal glycogen accumulation with very long outer branches. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anderson disease

 

  • Anderson disease (Glycogen storage disease Type IV, also known as Branching enzyme deficiency) is characterized by abnormal glycogen accumulation with very long outer branches.
  • It primarily affects the liver, leading to hepatomegaly and liver dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) is characterized by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired gluconeogenesis and glycogen storage in the liver and kidneys. It typically presents with severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and growth retardation, but it does not manifest with myopathy or muscle weakness.

 

Option B. Pompe disease (Glycogen storage disease Type II) is caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase) and leads to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes. It primarily affects cardiac and skeletal muscles, leading to muscle weakness and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This condition can also present with hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Cori disease (Glycogen storage disease Type III) results from a deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme. It can lead to glycogen accumulation with short outer branches and presents with hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, and myopathy.

 

  • Given the combination of hepatomegaly, myopathy, and abnormal glycogen accumulation with very long outer branches, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is Option D. Anderson disease.

choices.text: Duration of action is longer than filgrastim.
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally.
It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia.
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duration of action is longer than filgrastim.

 

  • Pegylated-filgrastim, also known as peg-filgrastim, is a long-acting formulation of filgrastim that is used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients receiving chemotherapy.
  • The addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to filgrastim increases its molecular weight and slows down its clearance from the body, resulting in a longer duration of action compared to normal filgrastim.
  • Pegylated-filgrastim cannot be taken orally, as it is administered by injection.
  • Pegylated-filgrastim is not contraindicated in sickle cell patients, but caution should be exercised as it can stimulate the production of white blood cells, increasing the risk of sickling crises.
  • Pegylated-filgrastim is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and can help to reduce the risk of infection in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

questions.text: Ananya, a 22-year-old female who has myopia visits the ophthalmologist and requests her to eliminate the need to wear spectacles in order to see clearly. The ophthalmologist examines her thoroughly, suggests her a surgery involving the cornea which can solve her problem. Of the outer fibrous coat of the eyeball, what fraction is contributed by the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior 1/6th

 

  • The outer fibrous coat of the eyeball consists of:
    • Anterior 1/6th = Cornea
    • Posterior 5/6th = Sclera

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.
  • Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease.
  • After the incubation period of 5-15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills.
  • By around 4-5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.
  • The infection can be transmitted by:
    • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
    • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva
  • The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. R. typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal. Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. R. akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. R. conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

  • Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia.
  • It is a B-cell tumour.
  • Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells.
  • Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells.
  • Annexin-A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes is posted for surgery. His HbA1c is 6 gm %. What is his ASA-physical status classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ASA -PS II

 

  • In the case presented, the patient is a 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes, and his HbA1c level is 6%.
  • A HbA1c level of 6% suggests that his diabetes is reasonably well-controlled, and it does not indicate severe systemic disease.
  • Therefore, the appropriate ASA-PS classification for this patient would be Option B. ASA-PS II (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status II).
  • American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status classification:
    • ASA-PS I (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status I): This category represents a normal healthy patient with no underlying medical conditions. Patients in ASA-PS I have an excellent chance of a successful outcome after surgery.
    • ASA-PS II (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status II): This category includes patients with mild to moderate systemic diseases. These conditions are well-controlled and do not limit the patient's daily activities. For example, controlled hypertension, well-managed diabetes, or mild asthma would fall into this category.
    • ASA-PS III (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status III): Patients in this category have severe systemic diseases that limit their daily activities. These conditions may not be well-controlled and could pose significant risks during surgery. Examples include patients with poorly controlled diabetes, significant heart disease, or severe lung disease.
    • ASA-PS IV (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status IV): This category is reserved for patients with severe systemic diseases that are a constant threat to their life. Patients in this category are often unstable and may require immediate medical attention. Examples include patients with decompensated heart failure, severe respiratory failure, or end-stage organ failure.
    • ASA-PS V (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status V): This category represents patients who are in a moribund state and are not expected to survive without the surgery. The surgery may be performed as a last resort to prolong life, even though the chances of survival are extremely low. Patients in ASA-PS V often have severe, life-threatening conditions and may be comatose or near death.
    • ASA-PS VI (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status VI): This category includes patients who have been declared brain-dead but are being kept on life support for the purpose of organ donation. These patients are not expected to recover, and their organs are being preserved for transplantation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • To interpret the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System and apply it to patients with chronic conditions to assess their preoperative risk.

choices.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication.
Obtain further information from the parents and teachers.
Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate.
Send the child for psychological assessment.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 8-year-old boy to the pediatric department as she suspects he has ADHD. At home he is always restless, never seems to pay attention, and is always losing things. In the OPD, the child is cooperative and has a normal examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obtain further information from the parents and teachers.

 

  • A physical examination (with emphasis on the neurologic component) is completed to identify any soft signs of neurologic conditions.
  • If none are found, he should undergo an ADHD evaluation with ADHD-specific behavior information obtained from caregivers and teachers.
  • A diagnosis is considered if he has ADHD-specific behaviors in two or more settings.
  • His ability to maintain focus during a brief visit to the OPD does not preclude the diagnosis of ADHD.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Before starting of a pharmacotherapy a complete evaluation including the family history and the social history must be obtained.

 

Option C. Reassurance must be done, only after a complete examination in the absence of the disease.

 

Option D. Psychological assessment must be done, only after a complete examination including collecting the family history and the social history

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai, 9th Edition, Page No. 56-59

choices.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
Complete vaginal atresia

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause.
  • O/e, a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina. This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option B. In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.

 

Option C. In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain is suggestive of an obstructive cause of amenorrhoea.
  • In an imperforate hymen, a bluish bulge distending the hymen is seen at the introitus.
  • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination.
  • Treatment of an imperforate hymen: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 450

choices.text: IV glyceryl trinitrate infusion
Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of chest pain with each episode lasting for 20-30 minutes and partial response with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He is a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia and currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injection enoxaparin

 

  • In the background of significant ASCVD risk factors and clinical presentation of ischemic chest pain with ECG changes, diagnosis of NSTE-ACS should be considered and hence, first line management in anticoagulants.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IV GTN can be used if pain is refractory, however, is not the definitive management.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel prevents thrombus propagation and formation, however, does not cause breakdown of the platelet rich thrombus (white thrombus) that is hallmark in NSTE-ACS.

 

Option D. Beta-blockers are used to reduce the ischemic chest pain in chronic stable angina, and cause LV remodeling with significant mortality benefit in patients with LV dysfunction.

 

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st edition, ACS, Chapter 273

choices.text: It is a water-soluble vitamin.
Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypocoagulability.
Excessive vitamin K intake can result in hypercoagulability.
Menaquinone is primarily found in green vegetables.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vitamin K is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypocoagulability.

 

Let's evaluate each statement based on the revised options:

 

Option A. It is a water-soluble vitamin. This statement is not true. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin, which means it is absorbed in the presence of dietary fat and is stored in the body's fat tissues.

 

Option B. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypocoagulability. This statement is true. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of blood clotting factors, including factors II, VII, IX, and X. Deficiency of vitamin K results in impaired blood clotting, leading to a bleeding tendency or hypocoagulability.

 

Option C. Excessive vitamin K intake can result in hypercoagulability. This statement is not accurate. While vitamin K is important for blood clotting, excessive intake of vitamin K is not associated with hypercoagulability. Instead, it can lead to reduced anticoagulant effects of blood-thinning medications like warfarin.

 

Option D. Menaquinone is primarily found in green vegetables. This statement is partially true. Menaquinone (vitamin K2) is one of the dietary sources of vitamin K, but it is not primarily found in green vegetables. Phylloquinone (vitamin K1) is the form of vitamin K primarily found in green leafy vegetables.

 

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Option B. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypocoagulability. This statement accurately reflects the role of vitamin K in blood clotting and the consequences of vitamin K deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive are not used in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol

 

  • Propranolol is a non-selective Beta blocker that is not used in Pregnancy.
  • However, Labetalol is a third generation Beta blocker with additional vasodilatory property which can be used as an antihypertensive.
  • Antihypertensive to be avoided in pregnancy:
    • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
    • Diuretics
    • Nonselective beta-blockers
    • Nitroprusside

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with chest pain, fatigue and diaphoresis. Patient previous nitrates did not give him relief for which he was rushed to the hospital. His ECG done showed ST-depression, and elevation of cardiac troponin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NSTEMI

 

  • NSTEMI occurs due to subendocardial ischemia and platelet rich thrombus.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Unstable angina produces no elevation in enzymes.

 

Option B. STEMI produces ST-elevations that are not seen in this patient

 

Option C. LV failure does not produce any particular pattern on surface ECG

 

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, ST-Elevations ACS, Chapter 275

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tracking of blood pressure

 

  • The phenomenon described in the question is tracking of blood pressure.

 

 

 

  • The WHO STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

questions.text: IPEX (Immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked disease) syndrome is caused due to mutation in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FOXP3 gene

 

  • Immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked disease (IPEX; OMIM 304790) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder.
  • The disease onset is in infancy and is characterized by severe enteropathy, T1D, and skin disease, as well as variable association with several other autoimmune disorders.
  • IPEX is caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene.

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition, page no. 2996

choices.text: Congenital herpes simplex virus infection
Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

  • The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection.
  • If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances.
  • More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.
  • Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles).
  • Triad: congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

choices.text: Non electrogenic Na+-Cl- symporter

questions.text: Amiloride can cause hyperkalemia due to its action on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electrogenic Na+ channels

 

  • Amiloride and triamterene are K+ sparing diuretics that act by inhibiting epithelial Na+ channels.
  • In the distal tubules and collecting ducts, three separate channels are present (one for Na+, K+ and H+ each).
  • Aldosterone acts on DCT and CD to cause reabsorption of Na+.
  • This generates a lumen negative potential difference across the membrane of this part of the nephron.
  • To maintain the electric neutrality, K+ and H+ are secreted in the lumen.
  • When amiloride and triamterene inhibits epithelial Na+ channels, transepithelial potential difference is not generated and therefore K+ and H+ are not secreted in the lumen.
  • Thus, due to more retention of K+, amiloride may result in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

  • Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations.
  • It is being transmitted with equal frequency from affected father to his daughters and son.
  • So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. 
  • The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome.
  • Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, including the skeleton, cardiovascular system, and eyes.
  • Important features of Marfan syndrome:
    • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs and fingers (arachnodactyly)
    • Aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm and dissection
    • Mitral valve prolapses
    • Lens dislocation, which can cause visual impairment or blindness
    • Skeletal abnormalities, such as scoliosis and chest deformities
    • Stretch marks (striae) on the skin that are not related to weight gain or loss
    • Joint hypermobility
    • Autosomal dominant inheritance

 

 

 

  • The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing.
  • Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

choices.text: Notching of 4th to 9th ribs can be seen
Can be associated with Turner's syndrome
Reverse 3 sign is noted on barium esophagography
Erosion of superior border of ribs is noted

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old child for a regular pediatric visit. On examination, the temperature of legs was less than that of his hands, so you worked out for Pulse and BP, which revealed the presence of variability. Further, a Chest X-ray was advised which reveals the following findings. All of the following are true statements regarding this condition except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erosion of superior border of ribs is noted

 

  • Erosion of inferior borders of ribs are noted and not in the superior border, mainly 3rd to 8th ribs from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is common by late childhood in coarctation of aorta.

 

COARCTATION OF THE AORTA

 

  • Coarctation of the aorta, also called aortic narrowing, is a congenital condition whereby the aorta is narrow, usually in the area where the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum after regression) inserts.
  • Clinical features:
    • Very common diagnosis
    • Often diagnosed antenatally
    • Absent femoral pulses
    • Should be born in a cardiac center
    • If not detected antenatally, presents as sick infant with absent femoral pulses
    • No murmur, usually
    • Signs of right heart failure (large liver, low cardiac output)
    • May be breathless and severely acidotic
    • Associated with VSD and bicuspid aortic valve
  • ECG: Normal
  • Chest X-ray: Normal, or cardiomegaly with heart failure
  • Management:
    • Resuscitate
    • Commence prostaglandin E1 or E2 (5-20 ng/kg per min)
    • Ventilate early (before transfer to cardiac center)
    • Surgery 24 hours later, usually through a left lateral thoracotomy, to resect the narrow segment, unless the whole aortic arch is small, in which case the surgery is performed via a median sternotomy on bypass.
  • Option A, B and C are the true statements regarding Coarctation of Aorta.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition

choices.text: Anti TPO antibody
Anti-Thyroid stimulating antibody

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-thyroid receptor antibody

 

  • The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Graves’s disease.
  • The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients.
  • TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.
  • Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 
  • Anti TPO antibody and anti-thyroglobulin antibody is seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • Also know that in contrast to antibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase, TSI is almost never observed in other autoimmune diseases of the thyroid.

 

 

Ref: Robbins, 10th edition, page no. 1081

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding HPV genes is true? 

  1. E6 gene mutates the tumor suppressor gene Rb.
  2. E7 gene mutates the tumor suppressor gene Rb.
  3. HPV vaccine specifically targets L1 capsid protein.
  4. E6 gene mutates the tumor suppressor gene p53.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

  • HPV selectively infects the epithelium of skin and mucosa.
  • Its genes E6 and E7 inhibits the tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb respectively.
  • Once these genes are inhibited, their control on the progress of cell cycle is gone and the cell undergoes uncontrolled divisions.
  • Keratinocytes become immortal and leads to formation of warts and neoplasms.
  • L1 protein is specifically used to produce recombinant vaccines against HPV.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

  • Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation.
  • Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.
  • Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues.
  • Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF).
  • These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence, the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

  • Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image.
  • Myringotome is a surgical knife used for drainage of fluid from the middle ear.
  • Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially.
  • Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

 

  • In a patient with renal insufficiency and low urine output, the preferred antihypertensive medication would be one that does not affect renal function or worsen fluid retention.
  • Amlodipine is a good choice because it is a calcium channel blocker that does not affect renal function or increase fluid retention. It also has a long duration of action and is well-tolerated in patients with renal insufficiency.
  • Aliskiren, a direct renin inhibitor, and prazosin, an alpha-blocker, can lower blood pressure but can also cause fluid retention and worsen renal function. Aliskiren can also result in hyperkalemia.
  • Thiazide diuretics are ineffective in renal failure. Further these can cause electrolyte imbalances.
  • Therefore, Amlodipine would be the best choice in this case.

choices.text: Her mother also suffered from breast cancer
She had breast cancer in the other breast as well
Her age is 48 years at diagnosis
Her father suffered from breast cancer

questions.text: A woman with breast lump is scheduled to undergo modified radical mastectomy. You would counsel her to undergo gene testing for BRCA mutation in each of these cases except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Her mother also suffered from breast cancer

 

  • Gene testing is done in high-risk individuals where two or more relatives had breast cancer.
  • Indications for genetic risk evaluation:
    • An individual at any age with a known pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant in a cancer susceptibility gene within the family
    • Breast cancer diagnosed age < 50 years
    • TNBC diagnosed age < 60 years
    • Two breast cancer primaries
    • Breast cancer at any age with one or more relative with breast cancer diagnosed < 50 years, invasive ovarian cancer, male breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, high-grade or metastatic prostate cancer
    • Breast cancer at any age with two or more affected relatives
    • Male breast cancer
    • An individual with a personal or family history of three or more of the following:
      • Breast cancer, sarcoma, adrenocortical carcinoma, brain tumour, leukaemia
      • Colon cancer, endometrial cancer, thyroid cancer, kidney cancer, dermatological manifestations, macrocephaly or hamartomatous polyps of the gastrointestinal tract
      • Lobular breast cancer, diffuse gastric cancer
      • Breast cancer, gastrointestinal cancer or hamartomatous polyps, ovarian sex chord tumours, pancreatic cancer, testicular Sertoli cell tumours or childhood skin pigmentation

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporin has activity against methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ceftobiprole

 

  • Fifth generation cephalosporins (ceftobiprole and ceftaroline) are the only beta-lactams active against MRSA.
  • Ceftobiprole is a fifth-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that has activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
  • It has a broad spectrum of activity against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, including MRSA, vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE), and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone and Option B. Ceftazidime are third-generation cephalosporins that are not effective against MRSA.

 

Option C. Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin that also does not have activity against MRSA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been present for several days. He also reports constipation, bloating, and occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the likely diagnosis based on his barium enema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sigmoid diverticulosis

 

  • The clinical presentation and imaging findings in this patient are consistent with sigmoid diverticulosis.
  • The presence of multiple diverticula in the sigmoid colon is a hallmark feature of sigmoid diverticulosis.
  • The patient's constipation, bloating, and rectal bleeding are also common symptoms associated with sigmoid diverticulosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sigmoid volvulus would present with severe abdominal pain and distention, and a plain abdominal X-ray would show a characteristic "coffee bean" sign.

 

Option C. Sigmoid diverticulitis would present with fever, leukocytosis, and localized abdominal pain, and imaging would show evidence of inflammation or abscess formation.

 

Option D. Colorectal cancer would typically present with a change in bowel habits, rectal bleeding, and possible mass on digital rectal examination or imaging.

choices.text: More than 10,000 population were males.

Males and Females were equal.
None of the above.

questions.text: Sex ratio in a village of India was found to be more than 1000. Its total population was 20000. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) More than 10,000 population were females.

 

  • Sex ratio is the number of females per 1000 males

 

 

  • Currently in India, according to Census 2011, Sex ratio in 2011 was 943 females per 1000 males.

 

 

Ref: Park, 26th edition, page no. 564

questions.text: Which of the following represents a recent failure to receive adequate nutrition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wasting

 

  • Wasting represents recent failure to receive adequate nutrition and may be affected by recent episodes of diarrhoea and other acute illnesses.
  • Wasted child has weight for height score at least 2 standard deviations below median for WHO child growth standards.

 

 

Ref: Park, 26th edition, page no. 730

choices.text: Serum homocysteine levels can be used to assess thiamin (Vitamin B1) status.
Activation of erythrocyte transaminases is a test for riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency.
Elevated serum methyl malonate levels indicate a deficiency of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6).
FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test is used to evaluate folic acid (Vitamin B9) status.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vitamin assessment and related tests is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test is used to evaluate folate (Vitamin B9) status.

 

  • The correct answer is option D. FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test is used to evaluate (Vitamin B9) status.
  • Elevated levels of Formiminoglutamic acid (FIGLU) excretion are indicative of a folate (Vitamin B9) deficiency, not a cobalamin deficiency.
  • The other options (A, B, and C) are not accurate descriptions of the respective vitamin assessments and tests.

choices.text: Activation of histone deacetylase

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is receiving theophylline as part of her management plan. She reports increased urination since starting the medication. Theophylline causes diuresis by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism

 

  • Theophylline's diuretic effect is primarily due to its antagonism of adenosine receptors, leading to increased renal blood flow and diuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PDE 4 inhibition. Phosphodiesterase (PDE) 4 inhibition by theophylline is more related to its bronchodilatory effects rather than diuresis.

 

Option C. Activation of histone deacetylase. This mechanism is thought to contribute to theophylline's anti-inflammatory effects but is not related to diuresis.

 

Option D. PDE 3 inhibition. This is more related to theophylline's cardiac effects rather than diuresis.

 

MECHANISM OF ADVERSE EFFECTS OF THEOPHYLLINE

questions.text: You are a medical resident working in a busy hospital when a 25-year-old female patient is admitted with complaints of chronic fatigue, easy bruising, and hepatosplenomegaly. A bone marrow examination reveals cells with a characteristic appearance as shown in an image. In this clinical scenario, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta-Gluco-cerebrosidase

 

  • Beta-Gluco-cerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which can present with hepatosplenomegaly, and typically involve the bone marrow with the characteristic appearance shown in the image.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. α-L-Iduronidase deficiency is characteristic of Hurler syndrome or Scheie syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I), which can present with hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal abnormalities but does not typically manifest with the characteristic cells seen in the bone marrow.

 

Option B. Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly and bone marrow findings.

 

Option D. Beta-Galacto-ceramidase deficiency is associated with Krabbe disease, which can present with Peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy.

 

  • Therefore, in this clinical scenario, the most likely enzyme deficiency responsible for her condition is Option C. Beta-Gluco-cerebrosidase deficiency, which is associated with Gaucher disease and can result in hepatosplenomegaly and characteristic bone marrow findings.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence 

 

  • Performing a surgery under the influence of alcohol, resulting in patient harm, is certainly a case of criminal negligence, as it involves reckless behavior that endangered the patient’s life.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence. Surgeon’s actions, under the influence of alcohol, while performing surgery, could be considered a case of criminal negligence due to the recklessness involved, resulting in harm to the patient.

 

Option C. Therapeutic misadventure also known as Medical Maloccurence is when individual is injured or died due to some unintentional Act by a doctor/hospital and is not related to the quality of care provided. It is an unforeseen accident due to individual biological variations. Here no one is negligent. Whereas in the question the surgeon is negligent, that too criminally.

 

Option D. Dichotomy. or fee splitting or sharing is Giving of a commission by one doctor to another for referring, recommending, or procuring any patients for medical, surgical or other treatment. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by State Medical Council. Hence this option is incorrect.

 

Learning Objective:

 

PROFESSIONAL NEGLIGENCE

 

  • Negligence in medicine means that a doctor didn't do their job carefully and skill fully as they should have in a particular situation.
  • This failure to provide proper care led to harm or injury to the patient, or even the patient's death.
  • Negligence can be of 2 types:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the clinic complaining of chest pain that worsens with deep breathing. He describes the pain as a sharp, localized sensation that is exacerbated by certain movements of the torso. The patient denies any recent trauma or injury. A physical examination reveals tenderness over the costosternal and costovertebral joints. Radiographic imaging of the thoracic cavity is performed to assess the integrity of the thoracic joints. Which of the following types of joints is LEAST likely to be involved in the patient's thoracic pain based on the nature of the joints and the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synarthrosis

 

  • Given the patient's symptoms of pain worsening with deep breathing and certain movements, it is more likely that the pain is emanating from joints that allow for movement, such as symphysis or synovial joints.
  • Synarthrosis, being an immovable joint type, is the least likely to cause pain that is affected by movement or breathing. Therefore, the correct answer is option A, Synarthrosis.

 

 

  • Synarthrosis joints are characterized by a fibrous band of tissue that connects the structures, allowing for little to no movement.
  • In the thoracic cavity, an example is the 1st sternocostal joint.
  • These joints are typically not sources of pain due to movement because they are immovable, making them the least likely to be involved in this patient's pain, which worsens with deep breathing and movement.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Synchondrosis refers to primary cartilaginous joints, which are also relatively immovable joints where the bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example in the thoracic cavity is the costochondral joints. While these joints are not designed for movement, they can be involved in pain syndromes related to the ribs.

 

Option C. Symphysis joints are secondary cartilaginous joints that permit slight movement and are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints. These joints can be sources of pain, particularly in conditions that cause inflammation or degeneration of the fibrocartilage, as might be expected in a patient with a chronic respiratory condition.

 

Option D. Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity that allows for free movement. Examples in the thoracic cavity include the interchondral, sternocostal (except for the first), costovertebral, and costotransverse joints. These joints allow for the expansion of the thoracic cavity during inspiration and are commonly involved in movement-related chest pain, making them a likely source of the patient's symptoms.

choices.text: Red degeneration of fibroid
Torsion of fibroid
Sarcomatous change in the fibroid

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid 

 

  • Red degeneration occurs mostly in pregnancy. Due to thrombosis of capsular veins.
  • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever.
  • After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g. abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis)
  • Treatment:  Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia
  • Surgical management AVOIDED
  • Fever is not seen in all cases of Red degeneration

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pre-term labor. This is unlikely, as in preterm labor, the pain isn’t acute severe. It will be increasing in intensity and frequency and occurring at regular intervals. Preterm labor is also associated with cervical dilatation and effacement.

 

Option C. Torsion of Fibroid. This can happen in a pedunculated subserous fibroid but is quite a rare occurrence, it will be additionally associated with vomiting and will require surgical management.

 

Option D. Sarcomatous change is very rare and does not increase in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 275

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

  • Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine
  • Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)
  • MOA:
    • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
    • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
    • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Very sudden onset
    • Dramatic presentation
    • “Conscious seizures”
      • Generalized
      • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
      • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)
        1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine
        2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)
        3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)
        4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C. Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D. Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

      •  
  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies are associated with stiff person syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • This disorder is characterized by progressive muscle rigidity, stiffness, and painful spasms triggered by auditory, sensory, or emotional stimuli.
  • The associated antibodies target proteins (GAD, amphiphysin) involved in the function of inhibitory synapses using γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) or glycine as neurotransmitters.
  • The presence of amphiphysin antibodies usually indicates a paraneoplastic etiology related to SCLC and breast cancer.
  • By contrast, GAD antibodies may occur in some cancer patients but are much more frequently present in the nonparaneoplastic disorder.
  • GlyR antibodies may occur in some patients with stiff-person syndrome; these antibodies are more frequently detectable in patients with progressive encephalomyelitis with rigidity and myoclonus (PERM).

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition, page no. 729

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a chronic, progressive skin lesion on her buttock. On physical examination, a well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with deep-seated nodules is noted which was progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end as shown in the image below. Diascopy of the nodules reveals an "apple jelly" color. The patient has a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no history of active tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus vulgaris

 

LUPUS VULGARIS

 

  • This diagnosis correlates with the clinical features described in the vignette, including the chronicity of the lesion, the presentation of well-demarcated plaques progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, and the patient's history of a positive tuberculin skin test.

 

 

Above image depicts Apple Jelly Nodules

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals with moderate immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It presents with well-demarcated plaques that can have apple jelly nodules on diascopy.
  • This is consistent with the patient's presentation and history of a positive tuberculin skin test, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Psoriasis.

 

This typically presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most commonly on extensor surfaces, and scalp.

 

 

  • It is associated with systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis and does not produce apple jelly nodules on diascopy.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis.

 

  • It is a multisystem granulomatous disorder that can present with skin manifestations known as lupus pernio, which can appear similar to lupus vulgaris but is associated with systemic symptoms such as dyspnea, cough, and ocular involvement.

 

 

  • It can present with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, but rest of the features which are in favor of Lupus vulgaris help us to rule out this option.

 

Option D. Granuloma annulare.

 

  • This is a benign, self-limited dermatological condition that presents with annular plaques which are Non itchy and lack any scaling, present typically over joints and is not associated with the apple jelly nodules seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the clinical features of Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, including the well-demarcated plaque, deep-seated nodules, and the characteristic "apple jelly" colour on diascopy.
  • Understand the association with a positive tuberculin skin test and the chronic, progressive nature of the condition.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 27, page no.  27.21, 27.22; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1306

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria will survive even after 30 minutes of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

  • The method for sterilization of milk is pasteurization.
  • Methods:
    • Holder method: 63C for 30 minutes
    • Flash method: 72C for 20 seconds followed by rapid cooling to 13 or lower)
  • All non-sporing pathogen are killed except Coxiella burnetii which may survive.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 125

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartmann procedure

 

  • The image shows sigmoid resection, colostomy and closure of rectal stump.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Right hemicolectomy. Involves resection of cecum and ascending colon with ileo-colic anastomosis.

 

Option C. Anterior resection. Involves resection of rectum with colo-rectal anastomosis.

 

Option D. Abdominoperineal resection. Involves resection of rectum + anal canal with colostomy.

Ans. B) It does not have a lock to enable a faster procedure time.

  • An ovum forceps does not have a lock.

choices.text: Consolidation with air bronchogram

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Consolidation with air bronchogram

 

  • History is suggestive of pneumonia.
  • CT shows consolidation with air bronchograms.
  • Patent bronchus seen in the areas of consolidation is termed “air bronchograms”.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Mediastinal mass is seen only in either of the compartments of anterior, middle or posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion is a hyperdense sickle shaped opacity seen predominantly in the lower lobes.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic hernia occurs due to intra-thoracic movement of abdominal contents through a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Ref: Harrison, Respiratory, Pneumonia, Chapter 126

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

  • Faint glow or luminescence of vomitus and stool is seen in acute phosphorus poisoning.
  • The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mercury. Acute mercury poisoning may cause headache, nausea, cough, chest pain, bronchitis, pulmonary edema, fine tremor, and CNS symptoms. Stools are bloody with shreds of mucous membrane but luminosity of vomitus and stools is not seen in mercury poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Option B. Cadmium. Poisoning characterized by sore throat, irritant cough, nausea, excessive salivation, metallic taste, headache and cyanosis (‘cadmium blues’) cramps in the abdomen, diarrhea, myalgia, bone pain, fractures with osteomalacia. Luminosity of vomitus and stools is not seen in cadmium poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Calcium. Symptoms of hypercalcemia includes Weakness, fatigue, Nausea, vomiting, Shortness of breath, Chest pain, Heart palpitations, irregular heart rate and constipation. Faint glow or luminescence of stools is not seen in calcium poisoning hence this choice is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PHOSPHORUS POISONING

 

  • Phosphorus exists in two varieties.

 

 

  • Oral and skin burns, luminescent ‘smoking’ vomitus and stools with a garlic odor, and GIT and biliary damage characterize white phosphorus poisoning.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

  • A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.
  • Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.
  • Leptospirosis: Flu-like symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

  • Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis): severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.
  • Laboratory tests: Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.
  • Serotype-specific tests: Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae – specific IgM antibodies in human sera.
  • Treatment: Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone
  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

choices.text: Cervical spine pathology

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of persistent ear pain for the past two weeks. She has no history of ear infection, trauma, or hearing loss. On examination, her tympanic membranes are intact and there are no signs of infection. She has a history of dental caries and recently experienced a sore throat that has since resolved. Which of the following is the most likely source of her ear pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dental caries

 

  • The correct answer is B, Dental caries, as it is a common cause of referred ear pain and aligns with the patient's medical history.
  • The patient's ear examination findings do not suggest a primary ear pathology, making a referred source of pain more likely.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine pathology can refer pain to the ear through the C2 and C3 nerves. While this could be a source of otalgia, there is no specific information in the patient’s history or presentation that suggests a cervical spine issue.

 

Option B. Dental caries can cause referred pain to the ear via the trigeminal nerve (CN V), particularly its mandibular branch (V3), which innervates the teeth. Given the patient's history of dental caries, this is a likely source of her ear pain, especially considering her intact tympanic membranes and the absence of ear infection signs.

 

Option C. Tonsillitis can refer pain to the ear through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). However, the patient's sore throat has resolved, which makes current tonsillitis less likely unless there is an ongoing subclinical or chronic process.

 

Option D. Laryngeal cancer can refer pain to the ear through the vagus nerve (CN X), but this is a less common cause of referred ear pain and there is no mention of associated symptoms such as hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, or weight loss in the patient's history.

choices.text: Type IIB – white muscle
Type I – smallest in diameter
Type IIA – slow myosin ATPase activity
Type IIB – fast fatigable

questions.text: All of the following regarding different types of muscle fibers are correctly matched except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type IIA – slow myosin ATPase activity

 

  • Type I and type IIA muscle fibers will be red in color, whereas type IIB fibers are white colored fibers.
  • Type I muscle fibers are smaller in diameter compared to Type IIA and type IIB fibers.
  • The myosin ATPase activity will be slow in type I muscle fibers, but fast in both type IIA and type IIB muscle fibers.
  • Type I fibers are slow fatigable, whereas type IIB fibers are fast fatigable.

 

Extra edge:

 

  • Classification of fiber types in skeletal muscles:

 

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 108

questions.text: Sita, a 28-year-old woman, has been experiencing episodes of yellowing of the skin and eyes, along with persistent itching. After a thorough evaluation and testing, the doctor suspects that her condition might be related to impaired bile salt absorption in her intestines. Bile salts are essential for the digestion and absorption of fats in the intestines. The optimal site for maximal absorption of concern factor which aid in fat digestion is the:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ileum

 

  • Majority of the bile salts (about 94-95 %) from the bile will be absorbed into the bloodstream from the small intestine, especially in the distal part of ileum.
  • Around one-half of the absorption will take place by diffusion and the rest will be absorbed by an active transport through the mucosa of the intestine.
  • The reabsorbed bile salts will enter the portal circulation, reach the liver, absorbed into the hepatic cells and will be secreted again in the bile.
  • This is known as enterohepatic circulation of the bile salts.

 

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, page no. 442

choices.text: Below the level of the thyroid isthmus
Through the cricothyroid membrane
Above the level of the thyroid isthmus, violating the first tracheal ring
At the level of the sixth tracheal ring

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of smoking and chronic hoarseness is diagnosed with carcinoma of the larynx. His condition requires a surgical intervention to secure an airway. A tracheostomy is planned, and the surgical team discusses the appropriate level for incision. Which of the following is the most appropriate location for a tracheostomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Above the level of the thyroid isthmus, violating the first tracheal ring

 

  • The correct answer is C, which is the only indication for a high tracheostomy, given this patient's specific condition of laryngeal carcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Typically, a tracheostomy is performed below the level of the thyroid isthmus to avoid complications such as perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis. However, this may not be appropriate in the context of carcinoma of the larynx.

 

Option B. An incision through the cricothyroid membrane, also known as a cricothyrotomy, is usually performed as an emergency procedure to quickly secure an airway. It is not a typical site for a planned tracheostomy in the context of laryngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. In cases of carcinoma of the larynx, a high tracheostomy may be performed above the level of the thyroid isthmus, which might involve the first tracheal ring. This is the only exception to the rule of avoiding high tracheostomy because the larynx will ultimately be removed, and a new tracheostome will be created in a clean area lower down. This option is the most appropriate given the patient's diagnosis.

 

Option D. A tracheostomy at the level of the sixth tracheal ring is lower than typically necessary and could be technically more difficult due to the location. It is not the preferred site for a tracheostomy in patients with carcinoma of the larynx.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

  • The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.
  • The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen.
  • A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate.
  • In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen.
  • These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: A patient with a long history of alcoholism presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leucocytes. Investigation shows serum uric acid levels normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Gout

 

  • Patient with H/O alcoholism with swelling at left great toe and synovial Fluid Analysis revealing raised leucocytes, points most likely towards Acute Gout.
  • In acute flare of gout, Serum uric acid levels can be normal.

 

ACUTE GOUT

 

  • Sudden onset painful monoarticular arthritis or bursitis – Frequently nocturnal.
  • May be polyarticular in subsequent flares.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Uric Acid can be normal in ~25%
    • Arthrocentesis is gold standard
  • Crystals: Monosodium urate (Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent)

 

 

  • Approach to Arthritis

 

 

 

  • Synovial Fluid Analysis:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Septic Arthritis is acute onset mono arthritis. MC at knee > hip/wrist/shoulder/ankle. Also, Synovial Fluid Analysis usually shows >50000 cells/mm3. But question hasn’t specified any value.

 

Option C. Pseudogout occurs especially at knees, wrists and MCP joints.

 

Option D. Reactive Arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis, not monoarthritis.

choices.text: Growth hormone + E + P
No HRT needed
HRT only after 45 years

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea is diagnosed to have Turner Syndrome. What Hormone replacement therapy should be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone + E + P

 

  • 45XO is suggestive of Turners syndrome.
  • Hormone Replacement in Turner Syndrome:
    • Growth hormone (GH) therapy has become the standard of care for girls with Turner Syndrome (TS) and should be considered as soon as decreased linear growth velocity is apparent.
    • Final adult height is maximized if GH therapy is begun at a young age; and is positively associated with the duration of treatment.
    • Recent studies have suggested that treatment initiated prior to 4 years of age significantly improved height outcome.
    • Most girls with Turner require hormone replacement therapy for breast development, uterine growth, and bone health.
    • Hormone replacement therapy should be started at a time that coincides with normal female pubertal development.
    • Initial hormone replacement involves low dose estrogen monotherapy. Progestogen replacement is generally added 1-2 years after starting estrogen or upon breakthrough bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Best treatment of Turner syndrome is hormone replacement therapy with growth hormone, estrogen and progesterone.

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no. 374

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent tearing from her left eye. Examination reveals no significant eye redness or visual impairment. She mentions the symptoms are more pronounced in windy conditions or when she is tired. Further examination of the eyelid function reveals a slight delay in tear drainage. Which part of the orbiculari oculi muscle, involved in tear drainage and commonly affected in such cases, is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle)

 

Let's explain each option and its relevance to the patient's symptoms:

 

Option A. Orbital.

 

 

  • The orbital part of the orbicularis oculi muscle primarily functions to close the eyelids tightly, protecting the eye.
  • It is not directly involved in tear drainage.

 

Option B. Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle).

 

 

  • The lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for tear drainage.
  • When this part of the muscle contracts, it helps move tears toward the lacrimal puncta, small openings in the eyelids, for drainage.
  • Dysfunction or weakness of this muscle can lead to impaired tear drainage, causing symptoms like tearing or epiphora (excessive tearing).
  • In the patient's case, her symptoms of intermittent tearing and a slight delay in tear drainage point to a possible issue with the lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle.

 

Option C. Temporal.

  • The temporal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is involved in the general function of closing the eyelids.
  • It is not specifically responsible for tear drainage.

 

Option D. Muller’s muscle.

  • Muller's muscle, also known as the superior tarsal muscle, is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid (levator palpebrae superioris).
  • It is not directly involved in tear drainage.

 

 

 

  • In summary, the most likely answer is option B. Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle), as dysfunction of this part of the orbicularis oculi muscle can lead to tear drainage issues, which align with the patient's symptoms of intermittent tearing and a slight delay in tear drainage.
