choices.text: Severe malnutrition Refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition Teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition Teach the mother on how to feed

 

  • The weight for height of the child falls in between -2SD and -3SD as shown in the growth chart below, which is suggestive of moderate malnutrition and the mother should be taught to feed the baby properly.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition Assure the mother. This is wrong option as the child is coming between -2SD & -3SD so we need to advice the mother for proper feeding and diet.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition Home treatment. This is not the right option.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition Refer to nutrition rehabilitation center. This is incorrect as severe malnutrition is less than -3S.

 

Educational objective:

 

The parameter affected in acute malnutrition is weight for height (wasting) chronic malnutrition is height for age(stunting)

 

Moderate malnutrition is between -2 and -3 SD

 

Severe malnutrition is less than -3SD

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles/MMR

 

  • Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.
  • In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.
  • Contraindications of live vaccines:
    • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
    • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
    • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.
  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: 

 

  • Neuroendocrine tumor (arises from enterochromaffin cells, not epithelial).
  • Can occur in the stomach, but not epithelial in origin.

 

Option B. Lymphoma

 

  • Arises from lymphoid tissue, not the epithelial lining.
  • Most common gastric lymphoma: MALT lymphoma (associated with H. pylori).

 

Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)

 

  • Mesenchymal (connective tissue origin), arises from interstitial cells of Cajal.
  • Positive for c-KIT (CD117) and DOG1.
  • Also non-epithelial.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Creeping mesenteric fat is seen.
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creeping mesenteric fat is seen.

 

  • Creeping mesenteric fat is seen during laparoscopy/laparotomy and is perhaps due to transmural inflammation of bowel.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

Option C. The proximal ileum is an uncommon site of involvement in Crohn's disease, it is the distal ileum. In addition to the terminal ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, rectum, and perianal region.

 

Option D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

choices.text: Transient synovitis of the hip
Osteomyelitis of the femur
Septic arthritis of the knee
Reactive arthritis following a gastrointestinal infection

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a one-day history of refusal to use his left leg and a fever of 38.6°C (101.5°F). His mother reports that he has been irritable and has had a decreased appetite over the past two days. On examination, the boy is found to have warmth, redness, and swelling over the left knee, and he cries when the area is touched or moved. There is no history of trauma or insect bites. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septic arthritis of the knee

 

  • The correct answer is option C, Septic arthritis of the knee, because the presentation of fever, refusal to bear weight, and signs of inflammation at the knee joint are characteristic of this condition.
  • Septic arthritis is a medical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent joint destruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Transient synovitis of the hip is a common cause of hip pain and limping in children; however, it generally does not present with significant fever and localized signs of inflammation such as warmth, redness, and swelling that are observed in this case.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis of the femur would typically present with localized pain over the femur and systemic signs of infection. While osteomyelitis can lead to joint effusion if adjacent to the joint, the acute presentation and localization suggest a primary joint infection.

 

Option C. Septic arthritis of the knee is the most likely diagnosis given the acute onset of fever, refusal to use the leg, and signs of inflammation localized to the knee joint. It is the most common joint affected by septic arthritis, particularly in the pediatric population.

 

Option D. Reactive arthritis following a gastrointestinal infection often presents with arthritis symptoms after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. However, this typically does not present with the acute onset of localized warmth, redness, and significant fever as in this case.

choices.text: Cost effective analysis
Cost benefit analysis

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cost benefit analysis

 

  • Monetary benefit is measured in Cost benefit analysis.
  • CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis]: Results of a programme analysed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $
  • CEA [Cost Effective Analysis]: Output of a programme analysed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.
  • Input-Output Analysis: Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)
  • Network Analysis: It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of frontal headaches with his father. His medical history is significant for complex partial seizures. He describes a typical seizure beginning with 20 seconds of involuntary oro-buccal movements. This is followed by approximately 40 seconds during which he experiences altered consciousness. Notably, at the onset of his seizures, he reports a compelling and uncontrollable urge to repeatedly think of the word ‘Prashamsansan.’ He is unable to suppress this thought, which persists throughout the seizure episode. His neurological examination and routine blood work are unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows no structural abnormalities. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced thinking

 

  • The phenomenon described by the patient, where he experiences a compelling and uncontrollable urge to repeatedly think of a specific word during his seizure episode, is known as "forced thinking."
  • This is a rare manifestation of complex partial seizures where the individual experiences an involuntary, repetitive, and often intrusive thought or cognitive process.
  • It's distinct from typical aura symptoms and is specifically associated with seizure activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Obsession. While obsessions, as seen in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), are also characterized by repetitive thoughts, they are not limited to seizure episodes and typically persist outside of such episodes. The patient's experience is specifically tied to his seizure activity.

 

Option C. Compulsion. Compulsions involve repetitive behaviors or mental acts in response to an obsession. The patient's experience does not describe a behavior or mental act performed in response to an obsession; rather, it is an involuntary thought process occurring during seizures.

 

Option D. Forced normalization. This term refers to a phenomenon where the EEG (electroencephalogram) patterns of a patient with epilepsy become normalized or less abnormal, typically in the context of an increase in psychiatric symptoms. It does not relate to the specific symptom described by the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Forced thinking is a type of psychic aura that is characterized by recurrent intrusive thoughts, or ideas, which subside on seizure activity.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page no. 510

questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-iii, 2-ii, 3-iv, 4-i

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liddle’s Syndrome

 

 

  • Hypokalemia + HTN causes Aldosterone Activation
    • Liddle syndrome (ENaC channel Gain of function mutation)
    • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (AME) (11Beta-HSD loss of function)
    • ↓11-βHSD → ↑Cortisol → ↑ Stimulation of MR receptor → HTN + Hypokalemia + alkalosis
    • Geller Syndrome (Mineralocorticoid mutation responding to progesterone): Presents in pregnancy. Rx with specific drug like Finerenone.
    • Glucocorticoid remediable Hyperaldosteronism (GRA): Chimeric gene b/w CYP11B1, B2 causing ACTH driven hyperaldosteronism.
    • Primary Hyperaldosteronism

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome mimics loop diuretics which occur due to loss of function of Na+-K+-2Cl- transporter at the Loop of Henle. Often patient has NORMOTENSION.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome mimics thiazide diuretic occurring due to loss of function mutation of Na+-Cl- transporter in DCT.

 

Both Bartter and Gitelman syndrome are normotensive.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome is opposite of Gitelman syndrome characterized by Gain of function mutation to Na+-Cl- channel which occurs either due to GOF of WNT1 pathway (OR) LOF of WNT 4 pathway, leads to inhibition of ROMK channel causing HYPERKALEMIA.

 

Note: Gordon = HTN + Hyperkalemia

 

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, Physiology of Kidney, Chapter 309, Table 309-1

choices.text: Punch biopsy forceps

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes dilation and curettage for abnormal uterine bleeding. Identify this instrument used in the procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine curette

 

  • This is an image of a uterine curette.
  • It is used for curetting the endometrium in the following procedures:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Following suction evacuation in MTP

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovum forceps.

 

 

Option B. Punch Biopsy forceps.

 

 

Option C. Tenaculum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • A uterine curette looks like this and is used for curetting the endometrium in the following procedures:
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Following suction evacuation in MTP
  • It has a sharp end (used in gyn procedures) and a blunt end (used in obstetric procedures).

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition, Page no. 523

choices.text: Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section
Acyclovir and induction of labor
Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (upto 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor. Vaginal delivery is contra-indicated in active genital herpes and hence there is no role for induction of labor.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery. Vaginal delivery is contra-indicated in active genital herpes.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery. Vaginal delivery is contra-indicated in active genital herpes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HERPES IN PREGNANCY

 

  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (upto 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective cesarean section.

 

 

Ref: High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options, David James, Philip J Steer, 5th edition, Page no. 673

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. His skin was dry and hot, face was flushed, pulse was fast and thready. Which of the following symptoms are least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating

 

  • The above case scenario is indicative of Heat Stroke.
  • It is very clear from the question that patient suffered a heat related illness (working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon).
  • The next step is to know whether it is heat stroke (a life threatening emergency) or other milder forms of heat related illness.
  • The clinical features of “collapse”, “thready pulse” indicate a severe illness.
  • In milder forms of heat illness, the pulse will be strong, moreover the chances of collapse are less.
  • Also, a very characteristic sign is “Dry skin”.
  • In milder forms of heat illness, the skin will be moist due to sweating, but in heat stroke it is dry due to the absence of sweating.
  • Hence it is a case of heat stroke, and answer is sweating.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin, Option B. Hypotension and Option C. Temperature 105.2F. All are the typical abnormalities seen in heat stroke as explained in learning objective below.

 

Learning Objective:

 

GENERALIZED EFFECTS OF HEAT

choices.text: Part of kidney involved

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Size

 

The size of the tumor is the most important determinant of malignant potential in papillary renal tumors.

 

Renal tumors of the papillary type include:

 

  • Papillary adenoma of the kidney (</= 1.5 cm)
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - greater than 1.5 cm

 

Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and are discovered by chance. One of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys is the ruling out of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunohistology: While useful for diagnostic and subtyping purposes, it is not the primary determinant of malignant potential. It helps identify the type of cells involved and the presence of specific markers.

 

Option C. Cytogenetics: Provides information on genetic abnormalities and can predict aggressiveness but is secondary to size in determining malignant potential.

 

Option D. Part of kidney involved: Although the location can affect treatment approaches and outcomes, it does not primarily determine whether a tumor is malignant; size is more predictive of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In papillary renal tumors, the size greater than 1.5 cm is the most critical determinant in assessing malignancy, outweighing factors like immunohistology, cytogenetics, and part of the kidney involved in terms of initial evaluation.

choices.text: Arrange blood and Crede’s method
Manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Following delivery, the placenta is being removed by traction on the structure shown in the image. The structure snaps and there is profuse bleeding. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Manual removal of placenta

 

  • The manuever shown is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver used in controlled cord traction for delivery of the placenta.
  • If the cord snaps, a manual removal of placenta is done otherwise the patient can start bleeding due to a retained placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin. This would have been given as part of active management of 3rd stage of labor. Even if not given, oxytocin should not be given till the placenta is delivered as the uterus can contract over the placenta making it more difficult to remove.

 

Option B. Uterine massage. This will not help in separation or expulsion of the placenta.

 

Option C. Crede’s method is NEVER done. It is expulsion of the placenta by fundal pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If the umbilical cord snaps during controlled cord traction, the placenta should be removed by manual removal of the placenta

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 1298

Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials?

Ans. B) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

OPEN VIAL POLICY

  • Open vial policy: Yes - Hep B, OPV, DPT, pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV
  • No open vial policy: BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid vaccines

choices.text: Lateral recumbent position

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman in labor has a transverse lie presentation. What maternal position is often recommended to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral recumbent position

 

  • The lateral recumbent position is often recommended for a patient with a transverse lie presentation to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation to relieve pressure off the cord.
  • Other recommended positions are: knee-chest and Trendelenburg positions

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Supine position. This is generally not recommended, especially in later stages of pregnancy, because lying flat on the back can cause the weight of the uterus to compress the inferior vena cava, reducing blood return to the heart and decreasing blood flow to the uterus and fetus. This is known as supine hypotensive syndrome.

 

Option C. Semi-Fowler's position. This position, where the woman is partially sitting up at a 30 to 45-degree angle, can sometimes be comfortable for the mother, but it does not specifically encourage the fetus to turn from a transverse lie to a cephalic or breech position.

 

Option D. Prone position. Pregnant women are generally advised against lying in a prone position (lying flat on the stomach) due to the discomfort and pressure it places on the uterus and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency.
  • If the FHR is +, immediate delivery is the RULE, and this has to be achieved as quickly as possible.
  • Till the time the cesarean s being arranged for/being done, the pressure over the cord has to be relieved by knee chest or lateral position/pushing presenting part away from the cord/tocolytic/filling the urinary bladder/Trendelenburg position.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no. 453

choices.text: ASHA must be resident of the village.
Have Formal education up to eighth standard.
In hilly and tribal areas, norms can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per hamlet/Habitation.
Should be in the age group of 18 to 60 years.

questions.text: In a survey, a tribal village was found to have more unmet need for contraceptives. It was decided to recruit and train ASHAs in the area. Which of the following is incorrect about ASHA?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Should be in the age group of 18 to 60 years.

 

  • ASHA must be resident of the village – a woman (married/widow/divorced) preferably in the age group of 25 to 45 years.
  • She should have formal education up to tenth class, having communication skill and leadership qualities. Educational qualification criteria may be relaxed if required.
  • The general norm of selection is two ASHA for 1000 population.
  • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 

 

Ref: Park, 26th edition, page no. 989

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG2

 

  • Deficiency of IgG2 results in recurrent sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated organisms.
  • Deficiencies of other IgG:
    • IgG1: bacterial infections (diphtheria, tetanus)
    • IgG3: viral infections
    • IgG4: parasitic infections
  • IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity to the newborn.
  • The antibody maximally transported across the placenta is IgG1, whereas IgG2 has the least transplacental movement.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

  • Immune responses that affect blood vessels, such in polyarteritis nodosa, typically display fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Grossly, PAN lesions appear as minute beaded nodules at the bifurcations and branching of vessel segments.
  • Antigen-antibody complexes accumulate in the blood arteries in several immunological diseases.
  • Complement activation brought on by these complexes causes type III hypersensitivity, which damages cells. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by deposition of fibrin-like material which has the staining properties of fibrin. It is encountered in various examples of immunologic tissue injury (e.g., in immune complex vasculitis, autoimmune diseases, Arthus reaction etc.), arterioles in hypertension, peptic ulcer etc.

 

 

 

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:
    • SLE
    • Libman-sacks endocarditis
    • Arthus reaction
    • Serum sickness
    • Polyarteritis nodosa
    • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
    • Malignant hypertension

choices.text: Halo nevus phenomenon
Reverse Koebner phenomenon

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the dermatology clinic with a skin lesion on the back. Upon examination, the lesion is identified as a melanocytic nevus with a noticeable eczematous halo around it. The patient reports that the halo developed a few weeks ago, and the lesion has been pruritic. Which of the following best describes the observed dermatological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meyerson phenomenon

 

  • The correct answer is Option D, Meyerson phenomenon, which accurately describes the presentation of a melanocytic nevus with an eczematous halo around it.
  • This is characterized by an eczematous halo surrounding a melanocytic nevus.
  • Patients may present with itching and erythema around a pre-existing mole, as seen in the image provided.
  • This phenomenon is not associated with malignancy, and the management usually involves topical treatments for the eczema.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The Halo nevus phenomenon.

 

  • This typically refers to a melanocytic nevus surrounded by a depigmented halo, often considered to be an immune response where the body's immune system attacks the pigment cells in the mole.

 

 

  • It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option B. The Reverse Koebner phenomenon.

 

  • This refers to the clearing and healing of psoriatic lesions following injury.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's presentation, as It is not characterized by eczematous changes.

 

Option C. Sutton's phenomenon.

 

  • This is also known as halo nevus, is similar to option A and describes a melanocytic nevus with a surrounding area of depigmentation, not an eczematous ring.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize and understand Meyerson phenomenon, which refers to the eczematous halo surrounding a pre-existing skin lesion, often a nevus, with associated pruritus and erythema.
  • This phenomenon is distinct from the depigmented halo seen in a halo nevus.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no. 39.27; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1108

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 hours

 

  • The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.
  • TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion.
  • The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:
    • Priming event: increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
    • Second knock: the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils
  • Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):
  1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
  2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
  3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
  4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
  5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
  6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
  7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
  8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
  9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
  10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
  11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.
  • TRALI vs TACO:

choices.text: Tolerable dose will deliver 40 to 60 mg of iron per dose.
Mass of total salt is important in determining daily dose.
Treatment should be stopped as soon as normal haemoglobin level is reached.
Desired rate of haemoglobin improvement is 0.5 mg per day.

questions.text: For oral iron supplements used for iron deficiency anaemia, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolerable dose will deliver 40 to 60 mg of iron per dose.

 

  • Tolerable dose of elemental iron is 200 mg per day in three divided doses i.e., app. 60 mg per dose.
  • Mass of elemental iron is more important in determining daily dose rather than mass of total salt because different salts provide different amount of elemental iron.
  • Treatment with oral iron should be continued even after reaching the desired haemoglobin level to replenish the stores.
  • Desired rate of haemoglobin improvement is 0.5 to 1 mg per week (not day).

choices.text: Restless legs syndrome
Sleep terror disorder
Periodic limb movement disorder

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife, who reports that her husband has been moving his legs constantly during sleep, leading to her being kicked multiple times each night. The husband states that he has no recollection of these movements. He mentions feeling fatigued upon waking up in the morning, despite sleeping for 7 to 8 hours each night. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Physical and neurological examinations are normal. Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Periodic limb movement disorder

 

  • The patient's symptoms are suggestive of Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD).
  • PLMD is characterized by involuntary limb movements during sleep, which the patient is typically unaware of but can significantly disrupt sleep quality, leading to daytime fatigue.
  • Key features supporting this diagnosis in this patient include:
    • Involuntary movements of the legs during sleep: The wife's report of her husband moving his legs constantly and kicking during sleep is a hallmark of PLMD.
    • No recollection of these movements: Patients with PLMD are usually unaware of their limb movements during sleep.
    • Daytime fatigue: Despite sleeping for an adequate duration, the patient feels fatigued upon waking up, indicating disrupted sleep quality.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Restless legs syndrome (RLS). While RLS involves uncomfortable sensations in the legs and an urge to move them, typically occurring in the evening or at rest, it does not usually involve involuntary leg movements during sleep that are reported by a bed partner.

 

Option B. Sleep terror disorder. This involves episodes of screaming, intense fear, and flailing while still asleep, often accompanied by sleepwalking. It is more common in children and doesn't align with the symptom of involuntary leg movements.

 

Option D. Narcolepsy. Narcolepsy presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (brief episodes of muscle weakness), sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periodic limb movement disorder (previously called nocturnal myoclonus) is characterized by repetitive, involuntary limb movements during sleep, often leading to sleep disturbance and daytime fatigue. It occurs primarily in NREM sleep. It is seen with folate deficiency, renal disease, anemia, and with antidepressant use. It is distinct from restless legs syndrome, which involves an uncomfortable urge to move the legs while awake and at rest.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no. 501

choices.text: Chevallet fracture – A vertical fracture line extending from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.
Jarjaway fracture – A horizontal fracture line starting just above the anterior nasal spine and running backward above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.
Le Fort I fracture – A horizontal fracture line above the teeth apices, separating the alveolar process of the maxilla from the rest of the maxilla.

Tripod fracture – A zygomatic fracture where the fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being involved in an altercation. He has noticeable facial swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the cheekbone and nose. A CT scan of the facial bones is performed. Which of the following descriptions best matches the likely fracture observed in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tripod fracture – A zygomatic fracture where the fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture.

 

  • Tripod fracture, also known as a zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture, is consistent with the patient’s presentation of cheekbone swelling and tenderness.
  • It involves separation of the zygoma in three places (hence "tripod"), and the fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture.
  • This type of fracture is commonly associated with trauma to the cheek area, such as a blow to the face, which is consistent with the history of an altercation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chevallet fracture typically involves the nasal bones, which would correspond with nasal deformity and tenderness, but might not explain cheekbone swelling and tenderness.

 

Option B. Jarjaway fracture describes a horizontal fracture of the nasal septum which would present with nasal symptoms but would not typically cause cheekbone swelling and tenderness.

 

Option C. Le Fort I fracture involves the maxilla and is characterized by a horizontal fracture line above the teeth apices. This fracture would likely present with mobility of the upper jaw rather than isolated cheekbone swelling and tenderness.

 

  • The correct answer is option D, Tripod fracture, as it best describes the likely fracture given the patient's facial swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the cheekbone consistent with the described mechanism of injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of severe headache, fever, and double vision. She recently had a dental abscess treated. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, and her visual examination shows impaired lateral movement of the right eye. There is no ptosis or pupillary abnormality. Her facial sensation is intact. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows evidence suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved first in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abducent

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with symptoms suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis, a rare but serious condition involving thrombosis (clot formation) within the cavernous sinus, a venous structure located behind the eye socket.
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis can result in a range of neurological deficits, particularly affecting the cranial nerves that pass through or near the cavernous sinus.
  • The cranial nerves most commonly involved in cavernous sinus thrombosis include:
    • Cranial Nerve VI (Abducent): The abducent nerve controls the lateral movement of the eye. It is often the first cranial nerve affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis due to its vulnerability as it passes through the sinus. Involvement of the abducent nerve leads to an inability to abduct the eye, resulting in horizontal diplopia (double vision).
    • Cranial Nerve III (Oculomotor): The oculomotor nerve controls most of the eye's movements, including the constriction of the pupil and the maintenance of an open eyelid. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, the oculomotor nerve is commonly affected, resulting in ptosis (drooping eyelid), pupillary dilation, and limited eye movement, except for lateral and downward gaze.
    • Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear): The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for downward and lateral eye movement. Involvement of the trochlear nerve would lead to vertical diplopia (double vision), particularly when looking downward.
  • The involvement of these cranial nerves is a result of their proximity to the cavernous sinus and its associated venous structures.

 

Other options:

 

Option D. Trigeminal. (Cranial Nerve V) The trigeminal nerve is primarily responsible for facial sensation and the motor functions of the muscles of mastication (chewing). In cavernous sinus thrombosis, the trigeminal nerve's involvement would manifest as facial sensory loss and chewing difficulties but would not cause eye movement disorders.

 

  • In summary, in this case of cavernous sinus thrombosis, the most likely cranial nerve to be involved first is Cranial Nerve VI (Abducent), as it passes through the cavernous sinus and its dysfunction results in an inability to abduct the eye, leading to horizontal diplopia.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium?

choices.text: Flumazenil should be administered intramuscularly for rapid onset of action.
Flumazenil should be used as a first-line treatment for all cases of benzodiazepine overdose.
Flumazenil may precipitate seizures in patients with a history of benzodiazepine dependence or withdrawal.
Flumazenil is not effective in reversing the respiratory depression caused by benzodiazepine overdose.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a suspected drug overdose. He is unresponsive and has shallow breathing. His medical history indicates that he has a history of benzodiazepine abuse. Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of flumazenil in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flumazenil may precipitate seizures in patients with a history of benzodiazepine dependence or withdrawal.

 

  • Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist of the benzodiazepine receptor and is used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • It can reverse the sedative and respiratory depressant effects of benzodiazepines and restore normal breathing and consciousness.
  • However, flumazenil should be used with caution in patients with a history of seizure disorders or benzodiazepine dependence, as it may precipitate withdrawal symptoms or seizures.
  • Flumazenil should be administered intravenously, rather than intramuscularly, for rapid onset of action.
  • Flumazenil is not a first-line treatment for all cases of benzodiazepine overdose, as supportive care and airway management should be prioritized.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

  • A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.
  • Clinical features:
    • Massive eosinophilia
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
    • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc.
    • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
    • Elephantiasis: It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

questions.text: Transitional cell carcinoma bladder is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schistosomiasis

 

  • Transitional Cell Carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder, also known as urothelial carcinoma, is the most common type of bladder cancer in developed countries. However, its association with schistosomiasis (particularly Schistosoma haematobium) needs some clarification.
  • Schistosoma haematobium infections in endemic areas like Egypt and Sudan are an established risk.
  • The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response that induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances, neoplasia.
  • Most of these cancers are squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Ref: Robbins, 10thedition, page no. 960

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: The hard palate contains:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

  • Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa.
  • The histology of the hard palate involves several layers and structures that provide its unique characteristics.
  • Here is an overview of the histological features of the hard palate:
    • Stratified Squamous Epithelium: The hard palate is lined by a stratified squamous epithelium, which is a multi-layered arrangement of cells.
    • Keratinization: The superficial layers of the stratified squamous epithelium of the hard palate undergo keratinization. Keratinized epithelium is associated with high connective tissue papillae. In the oral cavity, this type of keratinization is known as orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium. mucosa that covers the hard palate has a distinct keratinized layer known as the stratum corneum. Capillaries also loop up into connective tissue papillae.

Note: In orthokeratinized epithelium, cell nuclei disappear in the keratinized layer, Parakeratinized epithelium – flattened, highly condensed nuclei remain in the keratinized layer's cell cytoplasm until exfoliation

  • Lamina Propria: Beneath the stratified squamous epithelium lies the lamina propria, a layer of loose connective tissue.
  • Submucosa: Deeper to the lamina propria, there is a layer of dense connective tissue known as the submucosa. The central part of the hard palate's bony structure is covered by a firmly attached mucosa. The hard palate has a submucosal layer with blood vessels in the lateral parts. Minor mucous salivary glands can be found in the submucosa in the back of the hard palate.
  • Minor Salivary Glands: Scattered within the submucosa and lamina propria, you can find minor salivary glands. These glands produce saliva, which helps with digestion and oral lubrication.
  • Bone: The hard palate also includes the palatine bones, which form the hard, bony structure of the palate.

choices.text: Ultrasound of abdomen
Use of enuresis alarm

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy with complaints of bedwetting. On asking history, she informs that he does about 3 to 4 times per week. On further evaluation, he has a normal urine stream, daytime urine continence, and no history of UTIs. His physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of enuresis alarm

 

  • The clinical history in this 8-year-old child is suggestive of Nocturnal enuresis.
  • The next step in management is Use of enuresis alarm.
  • Nocturnal enuresis occurs in 15% of 5-year-olds with a resolution rate of 15% per year.
  • Males are more frequently affected, and family history is common.
  • Initial evaluation includes a history of wetting pattern, prior UTI, and developmental, social, and emotional history.
  • The enuresis alarm has a success rate of 70-90% and requires parental support.
  • Pharmacologic interventions include nighttime doses of imipramine or oral desmopressin acetate.
  • Following use of desmopressin acetate, fluid intake is restricted to avoid hyponatremia.
  • Pharmacologic treatment usually is reserved for special occasions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound of abdomen is not advised in case of Nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option B. Reassurance can’t be done in this case, as it’s a clear-cut case of nocturnal enuresis, which has got a definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Desmopressin acetate can be used in refractory cases of bed alarm therapy and special situations.

 

 

Ref: Nelson, 21st Edition, Chapter 558, Page No. 11044

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

  • The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.
  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder.
  • It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages.
  • It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone.
  • The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with localized pain in her left knee that worsens at night. She has no significant past medical history and reports no recent trauma. Physical examination reveals mild swelling and tenderness over the proximal tibia. Laboratory studies show normal white blood cell count and inflammatory markers. An X-ray of the knee is performed, revealing a well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margins in the proximal tibial metaphysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodies abscess

 

  • The correct answer is option A, Brodies abscess, as the clinical presentation and radiological findings are most consistent with this diagnosis. 
  • Brodies abscess is a subacute or chronic osteomyelitis, which often presents as a localized pain, typically without systemic signs of infection. 
  • The X-ray findings of a well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margins and no significant periosteal reaction are characteristic of Brodies abscess.
  • It is seen in the metaphysis of long bones (like the tibia). 
  • Pain is a common complaint, often worse at night. 
  • Systemic inflammatory markers can be normal in many cases, especially when the infection is localized and walled off. 
  • There might be localized tenderness and swelling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma: This is a benign bone tumor. It typically presents with nocturnal pain that is relieved by NSAIDs. It classically shows a small radiolucent nidus (usually <1.5-2 cm) with surrounding sclerosis on imaging, which may not be as well-defined as the lesion presented in the X-ray. Normal inflammatory markers are expected as it's not an infection.

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma: It is a vascular benign bone tumor, which is rare and typically does not present with the classic radiological findings of a Brodies abscess, such as well-demarcated sclerotic margins. Radiographically, it can be lytic, but often has a "sunburst" or "spiculated" pattern, or a "honeycomb" appearance. Pain is variable, not known for nocturnal exacerbation.

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma: It is a rare benign cartilage tumor that typically presents with a metaphyseal eccentric lytic area without the well-defined sclerotic margins seen in Brodies abscess. The lesion has a lobulated or scalloped sclerotic rim in the metaphysis of long bones. Pain is the main symptom, but not specifically known for nocturnal worsening or resolution with NSAIDs. Inflammatory markers would be normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both Brodie's Abscess and Osteoid Osteoma are known for nocturnal pain. 
  • The description of "a well-defined lytic lesion with sclerotic margins" and the x-ray finding better fits a Brodie's Abscess. 
  • An osteoid osteoma typically shows a very small lucent nidus with extensive surrounding reactive sclerosis, often obscuring the nidus without a CT scan. 
  • The lesion in the image is larger and clearly lytic with a distinct sclerotic border, which is highly characteristic of a Brodie's abscess. 
  • The normal inflammatory markers are also compatible with a walled-off, subacute infection i.e., Brodie's abscess.

choices.text: Prevent swarming of proteus
Differentiates LF and NLF
Helpful in the diagnosis of UTI specific organisms
Supports growth of Gram positive bacteria

questions.text: What is the main advantage of using CLED agar over MacConkey`s agar in the diagnosis of urinary pathogen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supports growth of Gram positive bacteria

 

  • CLED agar (Cysteine lactose electrolyte deficient) produces yellow colonies as lactose fermenters and green colonies as non-lactose fermenters.
  • Differential media:
    • This media helps to differentiates between two groups of bacteria by using an indicator, which changes the colour of the colonies of a particular group of bacteria but not the other group.
    • It differentiates lactose and non-lactose fermenters and inhibits the swarming of proteus.
    • Pseudomonas colonies are seen as greenish colour. Examples: MacConkey agar, CLED agar
    • The main difference between MacConkey agar and CLED: CLED has the additional advantage of supporting growth of GPC like Staphylococcus, Streptococcus and Candida species.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 29

choices.text: Inferior vena cava, right phrenic nerve
Esophagus, vagus nerve, esophageal branches of the left gastric artery
Aorta, thoracic duct, azygos vein
Thoracic vertebrae, spinal cord, intercostal nerves

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to his back. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg in his right arm and 90/60 mmHg in his left arm. A CT scan is ordered, which shows an abnormal dilation of the descending thoracic aorta. Concerned about possible complications, the attending physician explains to the medical student that the anatomical relationships in the posterior mediastinum are crucial for understanding the potential structures that may be affected by this patient's condition. Which of the following groups of structures is most likely to be involved if the patient's aortic dilation extends into the posterior mediastinum at the level of T12?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aorta, thoracic duct, azygos vein

 

  • The correct answer is option C, which identifies the structures at the T12 level that could be implicated in the patient's aortic dilation and the subsequent medical concerns.

 

 

  • The aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein are indeed located in the posterior mediastinum at the level of T12.
  • The aorta passes through the aortic hiatus at this level, the thoracic duct ascends through the posterior mediastinum next to the aorta, and the azygos vein arches over the root of the right lung to drain into the superior vena cava.
  • These structures could be compromised by an aneurysm or other pathological dilation of the aorta at the T12 level, potentially leading to life-threatening complications such as aortic rupture, compression of the thoracic duct leading to chylothorax, or obstruction of the azygos vein.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The inferior vena cava (IVC) and right phrenic nerve pass through the caval opening at the level of T8 in the diaphragm. Since the patient's condition involves the descending thoracic aorta at the level of T12, these structures are not immediately adjacent to the affected area and are less likely to be involved.

 

Option B. The esophagus, vagus nerve, and esophageal branches of the left gastric artery pass through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm at the level of T10. While these structures could be affected by an enlarging thoracic aortic aneurysm, the specific level given in the question (T12) is below the esophageal hiatus.

 

Option D. At the level of T12, the thoracic vertebrae and spinal cord are posterior to the aorta within the vertebral column. The intercostal nerves run along the underside of the ribs. While these structures are in the vicinity, the dilation of the aorta at T12 is more likely to directly impact the aorta itself and the associated vasculature and lymphatic structures listed in option C, rather than causing direct injury to the vertebrae, spinal cord, or intercostal nerves.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obstructive jaundice

 

  • Elevated ALP, conjugated bilirubin is suggestive of cholestatic pattern of liver injury seen in obstructive jaundice.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice. ↑ Indirect Bilirubin, Retic count, LDH; ↓ Haptoglobin.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice. ↑ Total, Direct bilirubin, ↑AST, ALT (> 3 ULN), Normal ALP (< 2ULN).

 

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st edition, LFT interpretation, Chapter 337

choices.text: Posterior or lambdoid fontanelle
Anterolateral or sphenoidal fontanelle
Posterolateral or mastoid fontanelle
None of the above as the remaining fontanelles should already be closed

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The mother expresses concern that the child’s head shape is different from that of her older child at the same age. On examination, the pediatrician notes that the child’s anterior fontanelle is closed. The mother asks when the other fontanelles are expected to close. Based on the standard ages of closure for cranial fontanelles, which of the following fontanelles would be the next to close in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above as the remaining fontanelles should already be closed

 

  • In this scenario, the most accurate response to the mother would be that all of the fontanelles should be closed at this stage in her child's development, assuming no abnormalities or delayed closure are present.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is option D, indicating that the remaining fontanelles should already be closed.

 

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The posterior or lambdoid fontanelle typically closes by the age of 3 months. Since the child in the scenario is 2 years old, this fontanelle would have already closed, and it would not be the next to close.

 

Option B. The anterolateral or sphenoidal fontanelle has a range of closure between 6 to 24 months. Given that the child is exactly 24 months old, this fontanelle may have closed already, although it could be the next to close if it were still open. However, without additional information suggesting delayed closure, we would assume normal development.

 

Option C. The posterolateral or mastoid fontanelle also closes between 6 to 24 months. This would place it in the same category as the anterolateral fontanelle, and similarly, it should have closed by now in a 2-year-old child.

 

Option D. Given that the anterior fontanelle, which is usually the last to close at approximately 24 months, is already closed, the other fontanelles should have already closed as well, according to the typical timeline. Thus, none of the other fontanelles would be the next to close in this child, as they should all be closed by this age.

questions.text: Which of the following medications inhibits the action of 5-lipoxygenase and consequently the action of leukotriene B4 and the cysteinyl leukotrienes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zileuton

 

  • Zileuton is a medication that inhibits the action of 5-lipoxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in the production of leukotrienes.
  • By inhibiting 5-lipoxygenase, zileuton can reduce the production of leukotriene B4 and the cysteinyl leukotrienes, which are inflammatory mediators that play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma and other inflammatory conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer that helps to prevent the release of inflammatory mediators such as histamine and leukotrienes.

 

Option C. Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of leukotrienes at their receptors.

 

Option D. Theophylline is a medication that has a variety of effects on the respiratory system, including relaxation of the airway smooth muscle and inhibition of phosphodiesterase, but it does not specifically target leukotrienes.

choices.text: Acute rotator cuff tear

questions.text: A 45-year-old tennis coach comes to your clinic complaining of severe shoulder pain that has been progressively worsening over the past six months. He notes the pain is most severe when serving the ball, particularly at the point of maximum arm elevation. On examination, you note tenderness over the anterior aspect of the shoulder and a painful arc of motion between 60° and 120° of abduction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Impingement syndrome

 

  • The correct answer is option C, Impingement syndrome, because the patient's clinical presentation and history are characteristic of this condition, which is common in individuals who engage in activities involving repeated elevation of the arm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder, typically presents with a progressive loss of both active and passive range of motion in all directions, not just pain at a certain arc of motion.

 

Option B. An acute rotator cuff tear may present with sudden pain and weakness in the shoulder following an injury, often with a decrease in active range of motion. However, the painful arc symptom is more characteristic of impingement syndrome.

 

Option C. Impingement syndrome is characterized by pain in the shoulder due to entrapment of soft tissues, most commonly the supraspinatus tendon. The painful arc of motion between 60° and 120° of abduction, tenderness over the anterior shoulder, and the patient's history of an activity that involves repeated arm elevation make this the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Glenohumeral arthritis usually presents with a gradual onset of shoulder pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion, often in all directions and not specifically during mid-range abduction.

Vertical transmission is possible.
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease.
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Rubella infection except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

  • Rubella infection in the 1st trimester: 90% have a significant risk for abortion and severe congenital malformations.

 

RUBELLA

 

  • Cause : RNA Togavirus
  • IP: 14-21 Days
  • Source: Cases [No carriers – No Iceberg phenomenon]
  • Mode of Transmission: Respiratory [Air droplets]
  • Period of Communicability: 1 week before rash ← SYMPTOMS → 1 week after rash
  • Vaccine: Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain [C/I in pregnancy]
  • 1st priority group: Non pregnant Non Lactating Reproductive 15-49 years female [1st trimester]
  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome: CVD [PDA], Cataract, Sensory Neural Deafness
  • Most common and most dangerous time for transmission of Rubella from Mother to Child is First trimester.

questions.text: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, is an essential nutrient for humans. However, humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of a specific enzyme. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the inability of humans to produce vitamin C?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

 

L-GULONOLACTONE OXIDASE

 

  • This enzyme is indeed responsible for the inability of humans to synthesize vitamin C.
  • Humans lack a functional L-gulonolactone oxidase enzyme, which is essential for the final step in the biosynthesis of vitamin C from glucose.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Xylitol reductase. Xylitol reductase is not related to the biosynthesis of vitamin C, and its deficiency does not contribute to the inability of humans to produce vitamin C.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase. Pyruvate dehydrogenase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism and the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. It is not directly related to vitamin C biosynthesis.

 

Option D. UDP glucose dehydrogenase. UDP glucose dehydrogenase is involved in the biosynthesis of glycogen, not vitamin C. Its deficiency does not contribute to the inability of humans to synthesize vitamin C.

 

  • Therefore, the correct answer is Option A. L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is the enzyme responsible for the lack of vitamin C synthesis in humans.
  • This deficiency is due to a genetic mutation that has rendered this enzyme nonfunctional in humans, unlike most other animals and plants that can synthesize vitamin C from glucose.

questions.text: In a psychological study, a subject is repeatedly exposed to a conditioned stimulus (a specific sound) without the presence of the unconditioned stimulus (a mild electric shock) that was previously paired with it. Over time, it is observed that the subject's conditioned response (a fear reaction) to the sound gradually diminishes. What is the process called where the strength of a conditioned response decreases after repeated presentations of the conditioned stimulus alone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extinction

 

  • The phenomenon described in the scenario is known as "extinction" in the context of classical conditioning.
  • Extinction occurs when a conditioned stimulus (CS) is repeatedly presented without the unconditioned stimulus (UCS) that it was previously paired with.
  • Over time, this leads to a decrease in the conditioned response (CR).
  • In the example given, the subject's conditioned fear reaction to a specific sound (the CS) gradually diminishes after repeated exposure to the sound without the accompanying UCS.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Conditioning. Conditioning is the process of learning associations between environmental events and behavioral responses. It can be either classical (associating two stimuli) or operant (associating a behavior with its consequences). This term is more general and does not specifically describe the reduction of the conditioned response.

 

Option C. Recovery. Recovery, or spontaneous recovery, is a phenomenon where a previously extinguished conditioned response re-emerges after a period of no exposure to the conditioned stimulus. This is not what is being described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Acquisition. Acquisition is the initial stage in classical conditioning during which the association between the CS and UCS is being learned, resulting in the formation of the conditioned response. This term describes the learning phase, not the diminishing of the conditioned response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the conditioned stimulus (specific sound) is repeatedly presented without the unconditioned stimulus (a mild electric shock), the response (a fear reaction) will diminish and eventually vanish. This process is known as extinction.

 

 

 

CR: Conditioned response; CS: Conditioned stimulus; UCS: Unconditioned stimulus

 

 

Ref: Psychology, Themes and Variations, 10th edition, Page no. 188

choices.text: Alkylation of DNA
Crosslinking of DNA

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the oncology clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening headaches and nausea. He has no significant past medical history. MRI reveals a large, heterogeneously enhancing mass in the right frontal lobe. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme. The patient is started on temozolomide. What is the mechanism of action of temozolomide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alkylation of DNA

 

  • Alkylation of DNA: Temozolomide adds a methyl group to the DNA molecule, causing damage to the DNA structure and preventing cell division.
  • Crosslinking of DNA: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like cisplatin and carboplatin, which bind to DNA and crosslink the strands, preventing cell division.
  • Microtubule inhibition: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like paclitaxel and vinblastine, which prevent cell division by inhibiting the function of microtubules.
  • Proteosome inhibition: This is the mechanism of action of drugs like bortezomib and carfilzomib, which inhibit the function of proteasomes, leading to the accumulation of misfolded proteins and apoptosis of cancer cells.

choices.text: Inherited defect in PIG-A
Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

 

  • CD55 or DAF (decay-accelerating Factor), CD59 or MIRL (Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis) deficiency occur in PNH, which leads to excessive destruction of red cells and leukocytes.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. It is an acquired X-linked defect.

 

Option B. Causes intravascular >> extravascular hemolysis.

 

Option D. Causes hemolytic, normocytic anemia, and pancytopenia with venous thrombosis.

 

 

Ref: Harrison, PNH, Chapter 100

questions.text: A 52-year-old male who is living with AIDS presented with fever, malabsorption, and chronic diarrhea. His stool examination showed the following finding with acid fast staining. Identify the causative pathogen.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryptosporidium parvum

 

  • There are three coccidian intestinal parasites that are acid fast.
    • Cryptosporidium
    • Cyclospora
    • Isospora
  • In this image, oocysts which are spherical or oval with size of 4-5μm are suggestive of cryptosporidium.
  • Cryptosporidium parvum is intestinal parasite that causes diarrhea (especially in immunocompromised patients).
  • Infective form: Oocysts; there are two types of oocysts:
    • Thick walled oocysts that cause infections to others
    • Thin-walled oocysts that causes autoinfection
  • The presentation of illness depends upon the immunity of the individual
    • Immunocompetent persons – self-limiting illness
    • Immunocompromised patients (AIDS) – life threatening diarrhea

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 500

choices.text: The tumor typically arises from the epiphyseal region of long bones after epiphyseal fusion.
The lesion often has well-defined, distinct margins on radiographic imaging.
Curettage with bone grafting is the standard treatment for this condition.
Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice for this type of lesion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of progressive knee pain. She denies any trauma but notes the pain intensifies with movement and at night. Physical examination shows mild swelling over the distal femur. Radiographs of the knee reveal an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of the distal femur with a "soap bubble" appearance. Which of the following statements about the likely diagnosis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice for this type of lesion.

 

  • The correct answer is Option D, as chemotherapy is not the primary treatment for giant cell tumors of the bone.

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Giant cell tumors (GCT) of bone typically arise in the epiphyseal region of long bones after epiphyseal fusion, usually in patients between the ages of 20 to 40 years. This statement is correct.

 

Option B. On radiographic imaging, GCT often presents as an eccentric lytic lesion with well-defined, distinct margins, often described as having a "soap bubble" appearance. This statement is correct.

 

Option C. The standard treatment for a giant cell tumor of bone is aggressive curettage with bone grafting or cement packing to fill the defect created by the removal of the tumor. In some cases, adjuvant therapies such as cryotherapy may be used. This statement is correct.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy is not the treatment of choice for giant cell tumors of bone. These tumors are typically treated with surgical interventions such as curettage and bone grafting. While there are systemic treatments for GCT that are resistant or unresectable, including targeted therapies like denosumab, chemotherapy is not a standard primary treatment option. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

choices.text: King’s college criteria

questions.text: A 50-year-old male, known case of cirrhosis of liver presents with abdominal lump. Imaging reveals solitary 3 x 4 cm nodule with rapid washout of contrast in venous phase. Which clinical criteria would decide suitability for treatment by liver transplant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Milan criteria

 

  • The given findings are suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
  • Transplantation for HCC, first described by Mazzaferro in 1996 for patients with tumours ≤5 cm or up to three nodules ≤3 cm, achieved 4-year overall survivals of 75% and recurrence-free survivals of 83%.
  • These inclusion criteria were adopted as the “Milan criteria”, with angioinvasion and extrahepatic involvement as additional exclusion criteria, and are now universally accepted.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Child’s score. Severity of chronic liver disease

 

Option D. King’s college criteria. For liver transplant in acute liver failure

 

Option B. Liver Imaging Reporting and Data System (LI-RADS) is both a set of standardized terminology and a classification system for imaging findings in liver lesions. The LI-RADS score for a liver lesion is an indication of its relative risk for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

choices.text: Great auricular nerve
Lesser occipital nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of a visibly enlarged nerve in the neck region, which he noticed a few weeks ago. He mentions that he often feels numbness around the area. Physical examination reveals a thickened nerve over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which is marked by an arrow in the image provided. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be enlarged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Great auricular nerve

 

  • Clinical considerations for the great auricular nerve include leprosy, where nerve thickening is present, and Frey's syndrome, which can cause gustatory sweating due to an aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and the great auricular nerve.
  • The clinical presentation, including the visibility and palpability of the nerve on the neck, points to the great auricular nerve as the correct answer.

 

 

  • The great auricular nerve is the largest ascending branch of the cervical plexus, which arises from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • It is commonly palpable in conditions like leprosy due to nerve thickening.
  • This nerve runs superficially enough to be visible in some individuals, especially in the presence of a pathological condition.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The lesser occipital nerve also arises from the cervical plexus and innervates the scalp in the lateral area above the ear. It is not typically visible or palpable externally, and its pathology would not present as visible thickening in the neck area.

 

Option C. The facial nerve is a cranial nerve (CN VII) that would not typically present as a thickened nerve in the neck. Pathologies of the facial nerve commonly result in facial paralysis, such as in Bell's palsy, rather than visible neck swelling.

 

Option D. The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve and would not present as a thickened nerve in the neck area. It is involved in Frey's syndrome, where patients experience gustatory sweating due to an aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and postganglionic parasympathetic fibers, but this condition does not cause visible thickening of the nerve like in the case presented.

choices.text: Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure
Endothelium independent coronary vasodilatation

questions.text: A patient of Prinz metal’s angina is started on isosorbide mono nitrate. What is the mechanism of action of nitrates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endothelium independent coronary vasodilatation

 

  • Isosorbide mono nitrate releases NO, causing coronary vasodilatation.
  • Prinz metal (Variant/Vasospastic angina) is the type of episodic angina that is due to coronary artery vasospasm which temporarily reduces blood flow to heart, producing ischemia, thereby causing pain.
  • It responds promptly to Nitrates and CCBs which reverse and inhibit coronary vasospasm causing relief in pain.
  • Mechanism of action of nitrates in Prinz metal angina:
    • When metabolized, organic nitrates release NO, that binds and activates guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to an increase in intracellular levels of cGMP, which through dephosphorylation of MLCK (myosin light chain kinase) leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation causing vasodilatation of Epicardial coronary arteries.
    • Vasodilation can be Endothelium dependent: Vascular smooth muscle relaxation by the production of endogenous NO (EDRF) from arginine using Enos present within vascular endothelial cells.
    • Endothelium independent: Vascular smooth muscle relaxation through the release of NO from NO donors e.g., nitrates. These drugs act directly on vascular smooth muscle to cause relaxation.

choices.text: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
Patients with chest trauma
All of the above

questions.text: In which of the following situations will you avoid the below procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

CONGENITAL DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA

 

  • In this condition, abdominal contents may herniate into the thoracic cavity, compromising lung function.
  • Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate this by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and further displacing abdominal contents into the chest, worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, it is typically avoided.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Obese patients. While BVM ventilation can be more challenging in obese patients due to anatomical considerations, it is not contraindicated. Appropriate modifications, like the ramp position, can be made to facilitate ventilation.

 

Option C. Patients with chest trauma. BVM ventilation is not necessarily contraindicated in chest trauma. It can be essential for providing life-saving ventilation, although care must be taken to avoid exacerbating certain injuries such as a tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. All of the above. “All of the above” is not the correct choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective for medical students is to recognize that BVM ventilation should be avoided in patients with congenital diaphragmatic hernia due to the risk of worsening respiratory distress by increasing intra-abdominal pressure, which can lead to further displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.
  • Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in:
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • Severe facial trauma
    • Rapid sequence induction

 

This is because it can increase intragastric pressure and cause aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18, and 21.

 

  • Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) a screening test for aneuploidy. (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  •  It has a sensitivity of 99% for the detection of Trisomy 21, 18 and 13.
  • NIPT utilizes cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum to screen for fetal aneuploidies.
  • NIPT is done after 10 weeks POG.
  • It is not a diagnostic test.
  • The diagnostic tests for detecting fetal aneuploidies are Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) a screening test for aneuploidy. (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • It has a sensitivity of 99% for the detection of Trisomy 21, 18 and 13.

 

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 890

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

  • To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb.
  • If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation, it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.
  • The best area to check postductal saturation is the foot.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Between left upper and right upper limb, we always choose right upper limb for pre ductal saturation.

Location of sapheno-popliteal junction

questions.text: A 35-year-old surgeon presents with calf ache and heaviness on prolonged standing. An imaging is done as shown below. The purpose of this sign is to identify:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Location of great saphenous vein

 

  • The above image shows “saphenous eye”, which shows the location of GSV in varicose veins.
