questions.text: You are a pediatric resident at a hospital, and a newborn is brought to the neonatal unit with a distinctive sweet odor in the urine and signs of poor feeding and lethargy within a few days after birth. In this clinical scenario, which of the following biochemical abnormalities is characteristic of this infant's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of α-keto acids in the urine

 

  • The presence of α-keto acids in the urine is characteristic of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).
  • MSUD presents with a sweet odor of urine, poor feeding, lethargy, and neurological symptoms due to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and their α-keto acid derivatives.
  • This matches the clinical presentation described.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. An elevation in serum phenylalanine is characteristic of phenylketonuria (PKU), a different inborn error of metabolism. PKU typically presents with intellectual disability and musty or "mousy" odor in urine and sweat but does not match the clinical presentation described.

 

Option C. Accumulation of glycosaminoglycans is associated with mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) such as Hunter syndrome and Hurler syndrome. These conditions typically present with different clinical features, including skeletal abnormalities and organomegaly, but do not match the described symptoms.

 

Option D. The presence of homogentisic acid in urine is characteristic of alkaptonuria, which leads to the darkening of urine upon exposure to air. This condition does not match the described clinical presentation of a sweet odor in urine, poor feeding, and lethargy.

 

  • Therefore, in this clinical scenario, the most characteristic biochemical abnormality is Option B. Presence of α-keto acids in the urine, which is typical of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: Which of the following gives the rate of drug absorption in plasma concentration vs time graphs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tmax

 

DRUG ABSORPTION CURVE

 

 

  • After taking a drug, levels peak quickly then drop slowly as the drug is eliminated (cleared from the body) – every drug has its own absorption curve.
  • The highest concentration is called the Cmax.
  • The total exposure to drug over the dosing period is called the Area Under the Curve (AUC).
  • The time taken to get to the highest concentration is called the Tmax.
  • The time taken to reduce the highest concentration by half (by 50%) is called a drug’s ‘half-life’ or T½.
  • It takes approximately 5 half-lives for a drug to be cleared to negligible levels, but in theory, tiny quantities can be in the body for much longer.
  • Tmax tells the rate of absorption of a drug whereas AUC tells the extent of absorption of a drug.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child opened his father’s drawer and ingested multiple tablets of his cardiac medication, metoprolol. The child was brought to hospital with profound hypotension and bradycardia. What is the specific antidote used in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucagon

 

  • The above case history is suggestive of beta blocker (metoprolol) poisoning.
  • Treatment of beta blocker poisoning:
    • Glucagon is physiological antidote. It stimulates the heart by increasing cAMP through stimulation of glucagon receptors in the heart. It acts independent of beta adrenergic receptors and is considered specific antidote of beta blocker poisoning.
    • If there is severe bradycardia, treatment with atropine is done and it may require pacemaker.
    • Other drugs useful in beta blocker poisoning in calcium gluconate.
    • Large doses of isoproterenol or an alpha receptor agonist may be necessary to treat hypotension in some cases.

Histidine and Lysine

questions.text: You are a medical student participating in a hematology rotation, and your attending physician asks you to explain the biochemical basis of a crucial component in blood clotting. You delve into the details of fibrinogen and its cleavage to form fibrin during blood clotting. Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A, a critical player in the clotting cascade?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

 

  • Fibrinopeptide A is a crucial component of the blood clotting process, specifically in the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.
  • The negative charge in fibrinopeptide A plays a significant role in its function.
  • Both aspartate and glutamate are acidic amino acids with carboxylic acid groups in their side chains.
  • These acidic side chains can ionize in solution, releasing hydrogen ions (H+), and result in a negative charge.
  • Therefore, aspartate and glutamate are responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glutamate and Valine. Glutamate is an acidic amino acid with a carboxylic acid group in its side chain, but valine is non-polar and uncharged. Valine does not contribute to the negative charge, so this combination is not responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A.

 

Option B. Histidine and Lysine. Histidine and lysine are both positively charged amino acids. They have basic side chains and would not contribute to the negative charge of fibrinopeptide A.

 

Option D. Serine and Threonine. Serine and threonine are polar amino acids, but they do not carry a net negative charge, so they are not responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A.

 

  • In summary, the correct answer is Option C. Aspartate and Glutamate.
  • These amino acids, with their acidic side chains, contribute to the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A, a critical component in blood clotting.

choices.text: V1 receptor – responsible for the modulation of vascular tone and peripheral vasoconstriction.

Ans. D) V4 receptor – predominantly situated in the central nervous system (CNS), modulating memory consolidation and cognitive functions.

 

  • There are only V1 (V1A), V2 and V3(V1B) receptors in our body.
  • V4 receptors are not seen.
  • The three types of receptors seen for the vasopressin in our body are:

 

 

  • These receptors can be explained as:
    • There are at least three kinds of vasopressin receptors.
    • V1A receptors mediate the vasoconstrictor effect of vasopressin, and vasopressin is a potent stimulator of vascular smooth muscle in vitro. 
    • The mechanism by which vasopressin exerts its antidiuretic effect is activated by V2 receptors and involves the insertion of proteins called water channels into the apical (luminal) membranes of the principal cells of the collecting ducts.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the neurology clinic with complaints of double vision. He reports that the double vision worsens when he looks down and to the right. The neurologist suspects a lesion affecting one of the cranial nerves and decides to perform a series of neurological examinations to determine the affected nerve. Based on the patient's symptoms, which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear nerve

 

  • Given the patient's symptoms and the associated functions of the cranial nerve nuclei, the trochlear nerve (option B) is the most likely to be involved in this case because its function directly relates to the movement of the eye in the described direction.
  • The trochlear nerve (IV) nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent (GSE) column, which controls the motor innervation to skeletal (voluntary) muscles.
  • The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which facilitates the movement of the eye downward and laterally.
  • Given the patient's specific complaint of double vision worsening when looking down and to the right, this nerve could indeed be involved.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The facial nerve (VII) nucleus is associated with the special visceral afferent (SVA) column, which is involved in the taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is not related to the motor control of the eye muscles and therefore would not directly cause double vision.

 

Option C. The vagus nerve (X) nucleus is part of both the general visceral efferent (GVE) column, which provides motor innervation to smooth muscles, heart muscles, and glands, and the special visceral afferent (SVA) column for taste sensation from the epiglottis. It does not have a role in the control of eye muscles and therefore would not be involved in the patient's double vision.

 

Option D. The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) nucleus is part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column related to taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue, as well as the general visceral afferent (GVA) and general visceral efferent (GVE) columns. It is not responsible for the innervation of eye muscles and would not be involved in causing double vision.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

  • Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
  • The autosomal dominant condition known as Huntington disease (HD) is characterized histologically by the destruction of striatal neurons and clinically by increasing mobility abnormalities and dementia.
  • All portions of the body move jerkily, hyperkinetically, and occasionally in a dystonic manner (chorea); affected people may eventually develop parkinsonism with bradykinesia and stiffness.
  • The average course of the illness is around 15 years before death because of its persistent progression.
  • The polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion illnesses have their origins in Huntington disease.
  • The HD gene, which is found on chromosome 4p16.3, produces the 348-kD huntingtin protein.
  • A section of CAG repeats in the gene's first exon encodes a polyglutamine region near the protein's N terminus.
  • The repeat is present in 6 to 35 copies in normal HD genes; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level it is associated with disease.
  • There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats are associated with earlier onset.
  • The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH = 7.2, HCO3- = 10 mEq/L, pCO2 = 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic Acidosis

 

STEPS

 

  • pH is on acidic side.
  • HCO3- in on acidic side (< 24 mEq/L), while pCO2 is on basic side (< 35 mmHg).
  • Therefore, Metabolic acidosis is the main metabolic abnormality which was compensated by respiratory system via decreasing pCO2 values.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presenting with diffuse back pain. Cervical spine X-ray shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

  • The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH), also known as Forestier disease, is a common condition characterized by bony proliferation of the spine affecting elderly individuals.
  • On imaging, it is typically characterized by the flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament involving the thoracic spine.
  • There is no involvement of the sacroiliac synovial joints.

She underwent colonoscopy which reveals the presence of dark black discoloration of colon (melanosis coli). Which of the following medications is most likely causing this discoloration of the colon?

It involves all three coats of the eyeball.

questions.text: Given below are statements regarding panophthalmitis. All are true except
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enucleation is the treatment of choice.

 

  • Panophthalmitis is a severe purulent inflammation that affects the entire eyeball, involving all three coats of the eye, including the sclera, choroid, and retina.
  • It is characterized by intense ocular pain, complete loss of vision, chemosis (conjunctival swelling), conjunctival congestion, and cloudy and edematous cornea.
  • Pus may also be present in the anterior chamber of the eye.
  • Complications of panophthalmitis can be serious and may include:
  1. Orbital cellulitis: Infection can spread to the tissues surrounding the eye.
  2. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Thrombosis (clot formation) within the cavernous sinus, a venous structure located behind the eye, can occur and lead to neurological symptoms.
  3. Meningitis: Infection can extend to the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
  4. Encephalitis: Infection may affect the brain itself, leading to encephalitis.
  • Given these complications and the potential for intracranial spread of infection, enucleation (surgical removal of the eye) is contraindicated in cases of panophthalmitis. This is because enucleation carries the risk of infection spreading through the dural sheath covering the optic nerve into the intracranial space.
  • Instead of enucleation, evisceration, an operation that removes the contents of the eyeball while preserving the outer shell (sclera), should be considered to avoid the risk of intracranial dissemination of infection.
  • Therefore, the statement "C. Enucleation is the treatment of choice" is not true; enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to the risk of intracranial spread of infection via the dura mater of the severed optic nerve.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

  • The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.
  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations.
  • These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable.
  • The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five.
  • When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps.
  • The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

  • Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

 

  • Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions.
  • There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50.
  • Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus
Superior temporal gyrus

questions.text: A 32-year-old right-handed woman comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in producing speech. She explains that she understands when others speak to her, and she knows what she wants to say, but she struggles to articulate her words. Her comprehension of language is intact. An MRI of the brain is ordered to assess the structural integrity of her brain regions involved in speech production. Based on her symptoms, damage to which of the following areas of the brain is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior frontal gyrus

 

  • The patient's difficulty in speech production without affecting comprehension suggests a problem in Broca's area, located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, which for most right-handed individuals is the left hemisphere.

 

 

  • This presentation is consistent with Broca's aphasia, often due to a stroke or other damage to the frontal lobe of the brain.
  • The inferior frontal gyrus, specifically Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), is responsible for speech production.
  • Damage to this area can result in Broca's aphasia, characterized by non-fluent, effortful speech with intact comprehension, which matches the patient's symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The superior temporal gyrus contains Wernicke's area (Brodmann area 22), which is critical for language comprehension. Damage to this area would cause Wernicke's aphasia, where the patient would produce fluent but nonsensical speech and have difficulty understanding language, which is not the case with this patient.

 

Option C. The angular gyrus is involved in the process of understanding written language and in complex language functions such as reading and naming. A lesion here could result in alexia or agraphia, but not in the type of speech production difficulty described by the patient.

 

Option D. The postcentral gyrus is the primary somatosensory cortex, responsible for processing tactile and proprioceptive information. Damage to this area would lead to sensory deficits, not speech production problems.

choices.text: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with elevated cholesterol levels and a history of alcohol abuse. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and there are signs of impaired detoxification. Upon further investigation, it is suspected that the patient's liver cells are not effectively metabolizing lipids. Which organelle's dysfunction might be contributing to the patient's lipid metabolism issues and compromised detoxification capabilities?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Smooth endoplasmic reticulum

 

  • The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is responsible for lipid metabolism and detoxification of drugs and toxins. 
  • The patient's elevated cholesterol levels and impaired detoxification suggest dysfunction of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The smooth ER's role in synthesizing and metabolizing lipids, as well as detoxifying substances, makes it a likely candidate for the source of the patient's problems.

 

 

  • Lipid are synthesized by smooth endoplasmic reticulum while proteins are synthesized from rough endoplasmic reticulum. 
  • The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a cellular organelle with complex series of membranous tubules and is present in the cytoplasm
  • There are two types of endoplasmic reticulum: Rough ER and Smooth ER 
  • Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER): also called as granular ER – ribosomes are present and are attached to the cytoplasmic side of the membrane
  • Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER): also called as agranular ER – no ribosomes
  • RER is involved in the synthesis of proteins, whereas SER is involved in the synthesis of lipids

choices.text: Steroid response elements

questions.text: In the investigation of a patient with a suspected endocrine disorder, the role of steroid receptors becomes paramount. When examining the molecular mechanisms involved in steroid hormone action, which of the following components would steroid receptors NOT typically bind to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transcription repressors 

 

  • Steroid hormones act as Transcription Repressors inside the cell.  
    • Several hormones, including adrenal and gonadal steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, retinoid hormones, and vitamin D, bind with protein receptors inside the cell rather than in the cell membrane. 
    • Because these hormones are lipid soluble, they readily cross the cell membrane and interact with receptors in the cytoplasm or nucleus. 
    • The activated hormone-receptor complex then binds with a specific regulatory (promoter) sequence of the DNA called the hormone response element, and in this manner either activates or represses transcription of specific genes and formation of messenger RNA.

choices.text: Malleus – First pharyngeal arch
Stapes – 1st pharyngeal arch
Stylopharyngeus muscle – Fourth pharyngeal arch
Cricothyroid muscle – Sixth pharyngeal arch

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes a physical examination during which the physician notes a symmetrical facial structure, proper occlusion of the jaw, and intact sensation over the face. The physician explains that these features are indicative of normal development and function of certain cranial structures that are embryologically derived from the pharyngeal arches. Which of the following structures is correctly paired with its corresponding pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malleus – First pharyngeal arch

 

 

 

  • The correct answer is option A, which correctly pairs the malleus with the first pharyngeal arch, matching the patient's features with the embryological origin of the structures responsible for his symmetrical facial structure, proper jaw function, and intact facial sensation.
  • The malleus, along with the incus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch.
  • The first arch also gives rise to the muscles of mastication (Temporalis, Masseter, Pterygoid), two muscles involved in the function of the ear (Tensor tympani, Tensor veli palatini), the anterior belly of the digastric muscle, and several skeletal structures including the maxilla and part of the temporal bone.
  • The normal development and function of these structures are crucial for facial symmetry, jaw function, and facial sensation, as observed in the patient.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The stapes are derived from the second pharyngeal arch, not the first. The second arch also gives rise to the muscles of facial expression, the posterior belly of the digastric muscle, the stylohyoid muscle, and several other skeletal components such as the styloid process, stylohyoid ligament, and lesser cornua of the hyoid bone.

 

Option C. The stylopharyngeus muscle is derived from the third pharyngeal arch, which is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). This muscle elevates the pharynx during swallowing and is not associated with the fourth arch.

 

Option D. The cricothyroid muscle is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch, not the sixth. The fourth arch is responsible for the formation of some laryngeal structures and is innervated by the superior laryngeal nerve. The sixth arch gives rise to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and is associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: While rescuing a child from a burning home, a firefighter was burned over 60% of his body. He is rushed to the emergency room and quickly taken into surgery. During the surgery, the anesthesiologist notices tall, peaked T waves and prolongation of the PR interval, accompanied by progressive widening of the QRS complex so that it appears to merge with the T waves. The patient goes into ventricular fibrillation, then asystole, and cannot be resuscitated. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for this patient's electrocardiographic changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Succinylcholine

 

  • The electrocardiographic changes described in the scenario, including tall, peaked T waves, prolongation of the PR interval, progressive widening of the QRS complex, and subsequent ventricular fibrillation and asystole, are indicative of hyperkalemia.
  • Among the options provided, the agent most likely responsible for the patient's electrocardiographic changes and subsequent cardiac arrest is Succinylcholine (option D).
  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used in anaesthesia for rapid sequence induction and tracheal intubation. However, it is known to cause a transient increase in serum potassium levels, especially in patients with burns or crush injuries. This increase in potassium can lead to hyperkalemia, which can affect the electrical conduction of the heart and cause the observed ECG changes and cardiac arrest.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Atracurium and other non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents do not typically cause hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Baclofen is a muscle relaxant used in the treatment of spasticity. It does not typically cause hyperkalemia or the described ECG changes.

 

Option C. Halothane is an inhalation anaesthetic. While it can cause hepatotoxicity and malignant hyperthermia, it is not directly associated with hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21-hydroxylase deficiency

 

  • Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female.

 

 

  • Likely cause: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency causing increased serum androgens
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), also known as adrenogenital syndrome, is a group of autosomal-recessive disorders that result from the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex.
  • CAH causes pseudohermaphroditism, where a genotypically normal female (46, XX) has external genitalia that resemble those of a male due to the increased production of androgens.
  • The most common cause of CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which accounts for more than 95% of cases with this disorder.

 

Note:

 

  • Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.
  • The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Pseudohermaphroditism of the female child is most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, comparable rates of remission were achieved for both a new treatment (33.2%) and the conventional treatment (32.2%). The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 (< 0.05) indicates that the results are statistically significant and there is evidence to suggest that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.
  • Although the difference in remission rates is small, it is still statistically significant, which means that the new treatment may have some clinical benefits compared to the usual treatment.

choices.text: Positive predictive value = 1 – Negative predictive value
Sensitivity is inversely proportional to specificity
Sensitivity = 1 – Positive predictive value

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to validity of the screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensitivity is inversely proportional to specificity

 

  • Sensitivity and specificity are inversely related.
  • Validity: It refers to the extent till which the test can accurately measure the values which it purports to measure. It is the accuracy with which the measured values agree with the true values.
  • It has two components: Sensitivity and Specificity. Both of these, together with predictive accuracy are inherent properties of the screening test.

 

 

Ref: Park, 26th edition, page no. 155

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with painful vesicles on his lip that erupted two days after he felt a tingling sensation in the area. He has had similar episodes in the past, usually during periods of stress or sun exposure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes labialis

 

  • The correct answer is Option D, Herpes labialis, based on the clinical presentation and the recurrent nature of the lesions described in the patient's history.

 

HERPES LABIALIS

 

  • This is commonly known as cold sores, is caused by the herpes simplex virus, typically type 1 (HSV-1).
  • It presents with recurrent painful vesicles on the lips that often follow a prodromal period of tingling or itching.
  • The patient's history of similar recurrent episodes triggered by stress or sun exposure, along with the clinical presentation, strongly suggests herpes labialis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Herpangina.

 

  • This is caused by the Coxsackie virus and is characterized by small, painful vesicles and ulcers on the posterior oropharynx, not on the lips.

 

 

  • Patients often present with a sore throat, fever, and malaise, which are not described in this vignette.

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum.

 

  • It presents with small, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules with a central umbilication, typically not painful, caused by a poxvirus infection.

 

 

  • This condition does not match the description of painful lip vesicles that are recurrent and associated with prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Impetigo.

 

  • This is a superficial skin infection characterized by honey-colored crusts and can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus species.

 

 

  • While it can affect the face, the presence of grouped vesicles with a history of recurrence and a tingling prodrome is more suggestive of herpes labialis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the clinical presentation of herpes labialis, including the characteristic painful vesicles on the lips that often recur, triggered by factors such as stress or sun exposure.
  • Understanding the etiology and triggers is crucial for appropriate management and counselling of patients with recurrent herpes labialis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no. 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1402

choices.text: Bromocriptine – Treatment of precocious puberty
Octreotide – Treatment of diarrhea associated with vasoactive intestinal peptide tumors.
Desmopressin – Treatment of diabetes insipidus
Leuprolide – Treatment of infertility

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs and its indications is matched incorrectly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bromocriptine – Treatment of precocious puberty

 

  • GnRH analogs are used in treatment of precocious puberty, bromocriptine has no role.
  • Octreotide:
    • An octapeptide analog of somatostatin
    • Effective in inhibiting the severe secretory diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome and VIPoma.
  • Desmopressin: Used in central diabetes insipidus, nocturnal enuresis and von-Willebrand disease.
  • Leuprolide:
    • Pulsatile administration is used for anovulatory infertility, delayed puberty, and hypogonadism.
    • Non-pulsatile administration is used for prostate cancer, precocious puberty, and endometriosis.
  • Bromocriptine: Used for treatment of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

choices.text: C1 esterase deficiency

questions.text: A 32-year-old man has got repeated attacks of Neisseria infection. Upon investigation, he was found to have immunodeficiency. Identify the component that he lacks.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Properdin deficiency

 

  • Terminal components of complements namely C5 to C9form the membrane attack complex (MAC).
  • Deficiency of any of these components leads to inability to form the complex that leads to predisposition of infection with Neisseria sp.

 

Other options:

 

Option D. Properdin and Factor D are needed to activate the alternative pathway. Hence, if that is not formed, MAC cannot be formed – indirectly, it also predisposes to Neisseria infection.

 

Option A, B. Early components – hence, ruled out. Their deficiency causes autoimmune diseases.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 206

choices.text: Dilated non reacting pupil

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Vogt’s triad following an episode of acute primary angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goniosynechiae

 

  • Vogt's triad is a set of clinical findings commonly observed following an episode of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG).
  • It includes three characteristic components:

        1. Glaukomflecken (Option A).

  • Glaukomflecken refers to anterior subcapsular lenticular opacities, which are small, white, opaque spots that develop on the crystalline lens of the eye.
  • These opacities are indicative of previous acute attacks of PACG.
  • They result from localized lens epithelial cell damage caused by elevated intraocular pressure during the glaucoma attack.

 

 

 

        2. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil (Option B).

  • During an episode of acute PACG, the iris sphincter muscle may undergo atrophy or damage due to the increased pressure within the eye.
  • As a result, the pupil becomes slightly dilated and does not react to light as it normally would.

 

        3. Patches of iris atrophy (Option C).

 

 

    • Iris atrophy occurs due to ischemic damage resulting from prolonged contact between the peripheral iris and the trabecular meshwork.
    • These patches of iris atrophy are another characteristic feature of Vogt's triad and can be observed in patients who have experienced acute PACG attacks.
  • The correct answer is Option D. Goniosynechiae.
  • Goniosynechiae refer to adhesions or synechiae between the peripheral iris and the trabecular meshwork.
  • While goniosynechiae can be associated with angle-closure glaucoma, they are not part of Vogt's triad.
  • Instead, Vogt's triad includes glaukomflecken, iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated non-reacting pupil.
  • In summary, Vogt's triad consists of clinical findings that are typically observed following an acute episode of primary angle-closure glaucoma, and it includes glaukomflecken, iris atrophy, and a non-reacting pupil.

questions.text: Which of the following zona pellucida proteins is responsible for zona hardening after sperm penetration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ZP2

 

  • The human zona pellucida contains at least four proteins, named ZP1, ZP2, ZP3 and ZP4.
  • In current physiologic models, receptors on the acrosome head of the sperm recognize ZP3.
  • This interaction releases acrosomal contents that permit penetration of the zona pellucida and ovum fertilization.
  • Enzymes released from the acrosome induce alterations in ZP2 that result in hardening of the coat.
  • This prevents fertilization of the oocyte by more than one sperm

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Receptors on the acrosome head of the sperm recognize ZP3.
  • This interaction releases acrosomal contents that permit penetration of the zona pellucida and ovum fertilization.

 

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no. 379

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?

choices.text: Inhibitor A decrease the affinity of enzyme for substrate.
Inhibitor B decrease the affinity of enzyme for substrate.
Inhibitor A decrease the Vmax of enzyme.
Inhibitors A and B has no effect on enzyme kinetics parameters.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are true statements regarding the inhibitors in this graph?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibitor A decrease the affinity of enzyme for substrate.

 

Inhibitor A decreases the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate.

 

  • This statement suggests that Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, as it does not affect the Vmax but decreases the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate.
  • This statement is true for competitive inhibitors.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Inhibitor B decreases the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. Inhibitor B is a non-competitive or mixed-type inhibitor, which affects the enzyme's Vmax without changing affinity for the substrate. So this statement is false.

 

Option C. Inhibitor A decreases the Vmax of the enzyme. This statement suggests that Inhibitor A reduces the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the enzyme. This is typically seen with non-competitive inhibitors, which compete with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme. However, Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor so this statement is false.

 

Option D. Inhibitors A and B have no effect on enzyme kinetics parameters. This statement indicates that both inhibitors have no impact on enzyme kinetics, which is unlikely based on the information provided in statements A and B.

choices.text: Intervertebral disc of C7-T1

questions.text: A 45-year-old construction worker arrives at the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and neck swelling after a heavy object struck him in the upper chest and neck region. On examination, there is notable swelling in the neck that increases with inspiration and a crunching sound on auscultation synchronous with the heartbeat. The trauma team suspects an injury to a cervical structure that may have led to the clinical presentation of subcutaneous emphysema and mediastinal crunch (Hamman's sign). Which of the following structures is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sibson's fascia

 

  • The presentation of neck swelling that worsens with inspiration and Hamman's sign suggests an injury to a structure that is involved in maintaining the integrity of the thoracic inlet and preventing air from entering the subcutaneous tissue.
  • Sibson's fascia fits this description, making it the most likely injured structure in this case.

 

 

 

  • Sibson's fascia, also known as the suprapleural membrane, is a structure that covers the apical portion of the lung and provides a barrier between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • An injury to Sibson's fascia could allow air to escape from the lung into the cervical fascia, leading to subcutaneous emphysema and the clinical signs observed in this patient.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The thyroid cartilage is part of the larynx and provides protection to the vocal cords. While trauma to the thyroid cartilage can cause neck pain and difficulty speaking, it is less likely to lead to subcutaneous emphysema and is not associated with Hamman's sign.

 

Option C. The carotid sheath contains the common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. Injury to these structures can lead to significant vascular and neurological symptoms, but they are not typically associated with the presence of subcutaneous emphysema or Hamman's sign as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. The intervertebral disc of C7-T1 is part of the cervical spine. While injury to the cervical spine can have serious consequences, including paralysis and respiratory difficulty due to diaphragmatic involvement, it is not directly related to the presence of subcutaneous emphysema or Hamman's sign.

choices.text: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
Steven Johnson Syndrome
Toxic Shock Syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the ER with high grade fever, body aches and diffuse erythematous rash. His past medical history revealed that he has underwent nasal packing 2 days back for epistaxis. What could be the best possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxic Shock Syndrome

 

  • The given clinical vignette with history of nasal packing is pointing towards Toxic shock syndrome.
  • It is a multi-system inflammatory disorder caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) of S. aureus.
  • The TSST-1 toxin is a super-antigen which causes spontaneous activation of >20% lymphocytes causing release of massive amount of cytokines.
  • The basic management involves removal of the packing and stabilization of the patient by giving appropriate supportive care.
  • Rapid infusion of IV fluids with careful monitoring of vitals.
  • Drug of choice: Clindamycin – reduces toxin synthesis.
  • Vasopressors may also be used for stabilization of the patient.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. It is mediated by Exfoliative toxin and is characterized desquamative epidermal lesions. The toxin is targeted against the Dsg-2 protein found in the epidermis.

 

Option B. Steven-Johnson syndrome. It is a drug-induced multisystem disorder characterized by involvement of <10% of total body surface area. There is history of patient being on Piroxicam, Lamotrigine, Allopurinol, Nevirapine, Carbamazepine etc. It may present with high fever, rash and systemic involvement.

 

Option D. Meningococcemia. It is a long term complication of Meningococcus infection in which the bacteria are present in the blood stream and invades multiple organ system. It is characterized by thrombocytopenia, purpuric rash, hemorrhage in the organs, most commonly bilateral adrenal hemorrhage called Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

choices.text: Lateral skull view

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He complains of facial pain, and the physical examination reveals tenderness over his maxillary and frontal regions. Radiographic imaging of the facial bones is ordered to assess for possible fractures. Which of the following radiographic views will best visualize the zygomatic arches and the base of the skull to assist in ruling out a fracture in these regions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Submentovertex (SMV) view

 

  • The correct answer is option C, Submentovertex (SMV) view, because it provides the best visualization of the zygomatic arches and the base of the skull, which are the areas of interest in a patient presenting with facial trauma and pain that may suggest a fracture in these regions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The lateral skull view is typically used to visualize the entire skull in a side profile. While it can show the profile of the zygomatic arches and the cranial vault, it is not the best view for assessing the base of the skull or providing a clear view of the zygomatic arches in relation to other facial structures.

 

Option B. The Caldwell view primarily visualizes the frontal sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, and the superior orbital rims. It is not optimal for viewing the zygomatic arches or the base of the skull as it is an anterior-posterior view with a focus on the frontal regions of the skull.

 

Option C. The Submentovertex (SMV) view is particularly useful for assessing the zygomatic arches and the base of the skull, including the foramen magnum and the mandible. It is less suited for detailed assessment of the maxillary sinuses, which is not the primary concern based on the patient's clinical presentation of zygomatic arch pain.

 

Option D. The Waters’ view is taken with the patient in a nose-chin position and is most suitable for assessing the maxillary sinuses. While it also visualizes the zygoma and zygomatic arch, it does not provide as much detail of the base of the skull as the SMV view.

questions.text: According to European Hernia society classification, a primary indirect hernia with 3 cm defect would be called as:
questions.solution:
And. D) PL2

 

  • The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of:
    • Primary or recurrent (P or R);
    • Lateral, medial or femoral (L, M or F);
    • Defect size in finger breadths (assumed to be 1.5 cm), with three sizes of one fingerbreadth or less, between one and three fingerbreadths and three or more fingerbreadths.
  • A primary indirect inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be PL2.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1067

choices.text: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
Ventricular tachycardia without pulse

questions.text: You are working as a medical resident in the cardiology department, and you receive a call from the emergency room. They are requesting your assistance with a patient who has just been admitted. The patient is a 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She presents with palpitations, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. On examination, her heart rate is 180 beats per minute, and an ECG confirms the presence of a regular narrow-complex tachycardia. In this clinical scenario, which of the following arrhythmias is NOT an appropriate indication for cardioversion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular tachycardia without pulse

 

  • Ventricular tachycardia without pulse is a life-threatening arrhythmia that requires immediate defibrillation, not cardioversion, as it represents a pulseless state due to disorganized ventricular activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) is a rapid heart rhythm originating above the ventricles and can often be successfully treated with cardioversion.

 

Option C. Atrial fibrillation is a common arrhythmia that can be treated with cardioversion, especially in cases where it is new-onset or symptomatic.

 

Option D. Atrial flutter is another atrial arrhythmia that can be treated with cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm.

 

  • Therefore, option B (Ventricular tachycardia without pulse) is not an indication for cardioversion. Instead, it requires immediate defibrillation to restore a perfusing rhythm.
  • Indications for Cardioversion:
    • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
    • Ventricular tachycardia with pulse
    • Atrial fibrillation
    • Atrial flutter
  • Indications for Defibrillation:
    • Pulseless ventricular tachycardia
    • Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infant mortality rate

 

  • Among these options, infant mortality rate (IMR) is overall best sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care in a community.
  • IMR = Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births × 1000.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with secondary amenorrhea for 2 years. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. She has no withdrawal bleeding after progesterone or after estrogen and progesterone. The likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asherman syndrome

 

  • This is most likely Asherman syndrome (intra-uterine synechiae) as there is no bleeding following a hormonal challenge of progesterone and estrogen.
  • This implies the problem is at the level of the uterus and not the HPO axis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCOS. This typically presents as delayed ovulation (delayed cycles) with hyperandrogenism and polycystic ovarian morphology on ultrasound. The LH:FSH ratio is characteristically increased

 

Option C. Cervical stenosis. This presents as secondary infertility and not as secondary amenorrhoea.

 

Option D. Gonadal dysgenesis. This presents as primary amenorrhoea usually and also will respond to an estrogen + progesterone challenge test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of Asherman syndrome is based primarily on a high index of suspicion, based on history.
  • In women whose history suggests this possibility, scant or no withdrawal bleeding after sequential treatment with exogenous estrogen and progestin reflects end-organ endometrial failure and corroborates the clinical suspicion.
  • Asherman syndrome is intra uterine adhesions.
  • They arise due to:
    • Surgical trauma to the uterus which may be seen due to the following:
      • Dilatation and curettage (esp. sharp curettage)
      • Cesarean section
      • Myomectomy where the endometrial cavity is involved
      • Metroplasty
      • Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Endometrial ablative procedures
    • Intra-uterine infections like tuberculosis and schistosomiasis
  • Symptoms:
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • Diagnosis
    • On ultrasound:
  • Uterine cavity appears irregular/ interrupted; punctate echogenic foci in the endometrium/ indistinct endo-myometrial junction/ endometrial fluid: commonly loculated appearing as small focal cystic areas within the endometrium
  • On HSG:
    • Intra-uterine filling defects are seen giving a moth-eaten appearance
  • Hysteroscopy:
    • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Treatment:
    • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis
    • Post procedure:
      •  To stimulate endometrial proliferation and prevent reformation of adhesions, oral oestrogen administration has proved effective. A cooper containing intra-uterine device can also be inserted to prevent reformation of adhesions
      • Another hysteroscopy or HSG is typically performed at 3 months following the initial resection.

 

 

Ref: Speroff’s, 9th edition, chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: A mother brings her 6 months old child for a regular visit. She complains that the child is vomiting very often. As you examined the child there is no abnormalities seen in the child. You reassured her that its normal and there is no pathology associated. She asks you what is the most common cause of this vomiting. What will be your reply to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerophagia

 

  • Aerophagia is the most common cause of vomiting in children.
  • Aerophagia, hydrophagia, and milkophagia are conditions related to swallowing behaviors, each involving the excessive intake of a particular substance.
  • Aerophagia refers to the excessive swallowing of air, leading to the accumulation of air in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • This can cause bloating, belching, and discomfort.
  • It commonly occurs in people who eat or drink too quickly, chew gum excessively, or have certain medical conditions affecting their swallowing reflex.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hydrophagia is the excessive or compulsive consumption of water. People with hydrophagia may drink large amounts of water rapidly and often, far beyond what their body requires. This behavior can lead to water intoxication, which may result in electrolyte imbalances and, in severe cases, can be life-threatening.

 

Option C. Milkophagia is the excessive consumption of milk or milk-based products. While milk is a valuable source of nutrients, excessive intake can lead to digestive issues like bloating, cramping, and diarrhea. Some individuals may have lactose intolerance, which can exacerbate these symptoms.

 

Option D. Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition where the esophagus does not develop properly, resulting in a gap that prevents food from passing between the mouth and stomach.

 

  • Option B, C and D are not the most common cause of vomiting in children.

 

Ref: Nelson, 21st Edition, Chapter 368, Page No. 8087

choices.text: Low tidal volume ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following strategies does not have a mortality benefit in ARDS?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early steroids

 

  • Early steroids have no role in the management of ARDS apart from COVID-19 related ARDS.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C, D are all lung protective ventilatory strategies to reduce mortality.

 

Option D. Prone ventilation of 16hrs/day is recommended.

 

 

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, ARDS, Chapter 301, Table 301-3

choices.text: Removal of belly piercings in abdominal surgeries
Hair removal just prior to antibiotic dosing on the OT table
Hair clippers are preferred to use instead of razors
Alcohol-based solutions like chlorhexidine are recommended on surgical site

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recommended essential step in preparing of surgical site prior to incision?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hair removal just prior to antibiotic dosing on the OT table

 

  • Hair removal is recommended after antibiotic dose is given, preferably on OT table.
  • Correct skin preparation can reduce surgical site infection (SSI) as below:
    • Removal of metals and other foreign bodies: Removal of piercings and rings from the surgical site is important as they often act as a nidus for infection. Metallic objects could also potentially lead to thermal injury when diathermy is used. In addition, finger rings or toe rings can cause digital vascular compromise if there is postoperative oedema following operations on the extremities.
    • Hair removal from the surgical site: Hair is removed from the surgical site when it is deemed to interfere with the operation. It also makes postoperative plaster or dressing changes relatively pain free. However, removal of hair causes micro-abrasions and can potentially cause cellulitis and SSI.
    • Timing of hair removal: The ideal time and place for hair removal is on the operating table after a dose of prophylactic antibiotic is given. Preoperative removal of hair outside the confines of the operating room is discouraged.
    • Skin antisepsis removes transient organisms and dirt, thereby preventing SSI. The use of alcohol-based antiseptic solution is recommended. The World Health Organization recommends the use of chlorhexidine alcohol; however, the clinical difference between povidone-iodine and chlorhexidine is marginal and therefore, the use of any alcohol-based anti-septic solution is acceptable.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 96-97

choices.text: Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol

questions.text: You are a physician working in an outpatient clinic when a 30-year-old male patient presents with complaints of enlarged, yellow-orange tonsils and intermittent episodes of neuropathy. Concerned about a possible underlying metabolic disorder, you decide to investigate further. In this clinical scenario, which of the following is a characteristic finding in his plasma lipoprotein profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol

 

  • Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol is a characteristic finding in Tangier disease, a rare genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in ATP-binding cassette transporter A1 (ABCA1).
  • This deficiency leads to impaired cholesterol efflux and results in low HDL cholesterol levels.
  • Tangier disease can manifest with enlarged, yellow-orange tonsils (tonsillar xanthomas) and neuropathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elevated HDL cholesterol is typically considered beneficial for cardiovascular health. It is not a characteristic finding associated with the clinical presentation described in this case.

 

Option B. Elevated LDL cholesterol is commonly associated with atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases but is not a characteristic finding in the context of the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Elevated chylomicrons in the plasma lipoprotein profile are typically seen in conditions such as familial hypertriglyceridemia, but they are not associated with the clinical presentation described in this case.

 

  • Therefore, the most appropriate answer in this clinical scenario is Option C. Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol, which is a characteristic finding in Tangier disease, explaining the patient's enlarged, yellow-orange tonsils and intermittent neuropathy.

choices.text: Necrotic myofibers with presence of neutrophils
Coagulative necrosis of the myocytes with presence of granulation tissue
Infiltration by histiocytes with hemosiderin laden macrophages

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with acute chest pain of 4 hours duration. Electrocardiographic examination revealed new Q wave with ST segment depression. He succumbed to his illness within 24 hours of admission. The heart revealed presence of a transmural hemorrhagic area over the septum and anterior wall of the left ventricle. Light microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotic myofibers with presence of neutrophils

 

  • The patient in the question succumbed to myocardial infarction after about 28 hours of the attack.
  • After twenty-four hours of the attack light microscopy shows coagulative necrosis of myofibrils with loss of nuclei and striations along with an interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edema in between normal myofibers:Too early (04 hrs); would not explain necrosis in the infarcted area

 

Option C. Coagulative necrosis of the myocytes with presence of granulation tissue: Appears after 710 days, not within 24 hrs

 

Option D. Infiltration by histiocytes with hemosiderin laden macrophages: Found after several days to weeks, associated with chronic infarcts or hemorrhage resolution

 

Timeline of Histological Changes After Myocardial Infarction:

 

 

Ref: Robbins, 10th edition, page no. 548

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Synchronized cardioversion

 

  • Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B. Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C. Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

choices.text: Insertion of LNG-IUS

questions.text: A 47-year-old P3 presents with heavy bleeding following periods of amenorrhoea. She has been experiencing this symptom on and off since several months now and attributed it to nearing menopause. On examination, her BMI is 30. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination is normal and a bimanual pelvic exam reveals a normal sized uterus. An ultrasound shows a thickened endometrium for which she undergoes an office biopsy. This shows endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. The best treatment option for her is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insertion of LNG-IUS

 

  • The LNG-IUS (Mirena) is the first-line medical treatment of simple endometrial hyperplasia (without atypia).
  • Continuous progestogens can also be used (medroxyprogesterone 10-20 mg/day or norethisterone 10-15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS. 
  • Treatment should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • Endometrial surveillance – at a minimum of 6-monthly intervals. 
  • In the presence of atypia, hysterectomy with b/l salpingo-oophorectomy should be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy. This is not the best management option as the risk of progression to malignancy (endometrial cancer) in endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is quite low.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation. This is not the preferred management in endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Combined oral contraceptives. Although they reduce the incidence of endometrial cancer, the preferred treatment is progesterone

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preferred treatment for Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia: Progesterone (LNG-IUS)
  • Preferred treatment for Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia: Hysterectomy with b/l salpingo-oophorectomy

 

 

Ref: Green-top Guideline No. 67 RCOG/BSGE Joint Guideline | February 2016

https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/green-top guidelines/gtg_67_endometrial_hyperplasia.pdf

questions.text: An outbreak in ICU being investigated, swabs from hands of healthcare professionals were taken and inoculated in blood and MacConkey agar the growth was seen as Non-hemolytic colonies in blood agar and non-lactose-fermenting colonies with faint pink tint. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter baumannii

 

  • Obligate aerobe, not fastidious
  • Blood agar: Non-hemolytic colonies
  • MacConkey agar: Lactose non-fermenting colonies with faint pink tint, promotes colonization by Unhygienic practices in hospitals – Contaminated hands of staff.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella pneumoniae, Option D. Enterobacter sp. Lactose fermenting colonies in MacConkey agar.

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis shows swarming in blood agar.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd edition by Apurba S Sastry

choices.text: All are correct

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents with lesion on face as shown. Which of these statements are incorrect?

 

 

  1. Slow growing
  2. Affects fair skinned
  3. Histology shows keratin pearls
  4. Lymphatic metastasis is common
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 4

 

  • Given image is suggestive of Rodent Ulcer/Basal cell carcinoma.
  • MC type of skin cancer.
  • Slow growing, locally invasive, no LN metastasis.
  • UV radiation is the MC risk factor.
  • Histopathology: Ovoid cells in palisading appearance

 

*Keratin pearls are seen in squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic back pain, especially pronounced upon waking up in the morning. Recently, she experienced a minor fall and has been having more difficulty in mobilizing due to increased pain. She has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis and has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy. A lateral spine X-ray is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on her clinical history and imaging studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The correct answer is option A, Osteoporosis, because of the patient’s demographic, clinical history, and characteristic radiological findings consistent with osteoporosis, including vertebral body compression and codfish vertebra appearance.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis is characterized by a reduction in bone mass leading to fragility fractures. It is common in postmenopausal women and can be exacerbated by long-term corticosteroid use, as seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The X-ray may show vertebral compression fractures, which can present as codfish vertebrae. Given the patient's age, gender, and medication history, this is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis of a vertebra. It is typically seen in younger patients involved in activities with repetitive lumbar extension and rotation. This condition does not usually present with codfish vertebrae on imaging.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one below it, often due to a defect in the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis). It may cause back pain but is not typically associated with the radiological findings of osteoporosis.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis, also known as marble bone disease, is a rare inherited disorder where bones harden and become denser. This condition would not present with the vertebral changes associated with osteoporosis and is not consistent with the patient's history or presentation.

choices.text: Tracheobronchial injury – Subcutaneous emphysema
Aortic injury – BP disparity between upper limbs
Pulmonary contusion – Worsening of hypoxemia in 24-48 hours
Diaphragmatic rupture – Hypoxia is common

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about injuries following chest trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diaphragmatic rupture – Hypoxia is common

 

  • Most diaphragmatic injuries are silent and the presenting features are those of injury to the surrounding organs.
  • There is no single standard investigation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Severe subcutaneous emphysema with respiratory compromise can suggest tracheobronchial disruption. A chest drain placed on the affected side will reveal a large air leak and the collapsed lung may fail to re-expand. Bronchoscopy is diagnostic.

 

Option B. Thoracic aortic injury should be clinically suspected in patients with gross asymmetry in systolic blood pressure (between the two upper limbs, or between upper and lower limbs), widened pulse pressure and chest wall contusion.

 

Option C. The natural progression of pulmonary contusion is worsening hypoxaemia for the first 24–48 hours. Chest radiographic findings may be typically delayed. Contrast CT scanning can be confirmatory. Haemoptysis or blood in the endotracheal tube is a sign of pulmonary contusion.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 376-77

choices.text: Intra-vesical DPT vaccine
Ileal conduit urinary diversion

questions.text: Which of these is not a component of management of muscle invasive transitional cell carcinoma of urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intra-vesical DPT vaccine

 

  • Intra-vesical BCG is used in non-muscle invasive bladder tumors.

choices.text: Lung with pulmonary thromboembolism
Heart with coronary thrombosis
Liver with hypovolemic shock
Kidney with septic embolus

questions.text: On sectioning of an organ at the time of autopsy, a focal, wedge-shaped firm area is seen accompanied by extensive hemorrhage, with a red appearance. The lesion has a base on the surface of the organ. This finding is typically of
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lung with pulmonary thromboembolism

 

 

Image of pulmonary infarct (marked by arrow)

  • The morphology is characteristically present as red (hemorrhagic) infarct. The red infarcts are seen in lung, liver and intestine.
  • White infarcts are seen in brain, spleen, kidney and heart.

 

 

Ref: Robbins, 10thedition, page no. 135

choices.text: The brain has four different genes encoding this protein

questions.text: A researcher introduces a human gene into a model organism to study its expression pattern. Using Northern blot analysis, he observes that in the brain tissue sample, there are four distinct bands. However, in the heart, kidney, and liver samples, he sees only a single band. Which of the following explanations could account for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alternative splicing

 

  • Alternative splicing is a process where different exons of a gene are included or excluded from the mature mRNA transcript, leading to the production of different mRNA isoforms from a single gene.
  • This process is tissue-specific and can result in distinct mRNA isoforms being expressed in different tissues.
  • Therefore, alternative splicing is the most likely explanation for the observed pattern of multiple bands in the brain tissue sample (due to different splice variants) and a single band in other tissues (due to a predominant isoform).
  • This is a common mechanism for generating tissue-specific gene expression patterns.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. RNA methylation. RNA methylation typically involves the addition of methyl groups to RNA molecules, which can affect gene expression and RNA stability. However, RNA methylation is unlikely to result in the specific pattern of bands observed in the Northern blot analysis. Methylation would not cause distinct bands in one tissue (brain) and a single band in others (heart, kidney, liver).

 

Option B. The brain has four different genes encoding this protein. This explanation suggests that there might be multiple genes encoding the protein of interest, and each gene may have different variants or isoforms that are expressed differently in different tissues. These isoforms could result in distinct bands on the Northern blot. However, this explanation does not involve post-transcriptional modifications like alternative splicing.

 

Option C. Protein folding variations. Protein folding variations can lead to differences in the mobility of proteins on a gel but would not explain the specific pattern of bands observed in RNA analysis (Northern blot). Protein folding is a post-translational event that occurs after the mRNA has been translated into protein. It would not result in different mRNA bands in different tissues.

 

  • So, the most likely explanation for the researcher's findings is option D. Alternative splicing, as it can account for the presence of distinct bands in the brain tissue sample and a single band in other tissues in the Northern blot analysis.

choices.text: True Koebner phenomenon
False Koebner’s phenomenon
Reverse Koebner phenomenon
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the clinic with multiple well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales scattered over her elbows and knees. She mentions that the lesions appeared after she had a minor abrasion on her elbow. Her medical history is significant for vitiligo but no other chronic diseases. Which of the following phenomena is most likely responsible for the appearance of her skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True Koebner phenomenon

 

  • The correct answer is Option A, True Koebner phenomenon, as the patient has developed psoriatic lesions at the site of trauma, which aligns with the characteristics of this phenomenon.

 

THE TRUE KOEBNER PHENOMENON

 

  • This is an immune-mediated response where new lesions of a pre-existing skin disease appear on otherwise normal skin following trauma.
  • This is commonly seen in conditions like psoriasis, vitiligo, and lichen planus.

 

 

  • Given that the patient has developed psoriatic lesions at the site of skin trauma, this is consistent with the True Koebner phenomenon.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. The False Koebner’s phenomenon.

 

  • This is related to the spread of infectious diseases such as viral warts and molluscum contagiosum along lines of trauma.
  • Since the patient has erythematous plaques with silvery scales typical of psoriasis and there is no mention of infectious disease, this option is less likely.

 

Option C. The Reverse Koebner phenomenon.

 

  • This refers to the clearing and healing of psoriatic lesions following injury.
  • This is not consistent with the patient's presentation, as she developed new lesions after trauma, not clearance of existing lesions.

 

Option D. The Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon.

 

  • This involves the spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the sites of trauma, such as autologous skin graft sites.
  • This is not applicable to the patient's current situation, as there is no mention of repigmentation or recent skin grafts.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize and understand the true Koebner phenomenon in psoriasis, where skin lesions develop at sites of trauma or injury.
  • In this case, the appearance of psoriatic plaques on the elbows and knees following a minor abrasion is characteristic of the true Koebner phenomenon.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook, 4th Edition, page no. 9; Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no. 4.9

choices.text: Associated cervical anomalies
Distortion of the uterine cavity
Distortion of the uterine serosal contour
Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum

questions.text: Septate uterus has a significantly higher spontaneous abortion rate and early pregnancy loss rate than bicornuate uterus. As illustrated in the figure below, what is the primary mechanism thought to be responsible for this extraordinarily high pregnancy wastage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Partial or complete implantation on the largely avascular septum

 

  • High pregnancy wastage likely results from partial or complete implantation on a largely avascular septum, from distortion of the uterine cavity, and from associated cervical or endometrial abnormalities.
  • In addition to spontaneous abortion, septate uterus may rarely cause fetal malformation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A septate uterus is associated with a higher incidence of infertility, abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction and malpresentations.
  • High pregnancy wastage likely results from partial or complete implantation on a largely avascular septum, from distortion of the uterine cavity, and from associated cervical or endometrial abnormalities.

 

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no. 449

choices.text: Ovaries should be conserved
Ovaries should be removed
Ovaries can be removed if they appear pathological
Ovaries should be conserved if patient is pre-menopausal and should be removed if patient is post-menopausal

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with biopsy proven endometrial cancer and MRI showing endometrial growth involving more than 50% myometrium is undergoing hysterectomy. What will be your advice regarding removal of ovaries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovaries should be removed

 

  • The recommended standard surgical procedure in this patient is an extra-fascial total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
  • Adnexal removal is recommended even if the tubes and ovaries appear normal, as they may contain micro metastases.
  • In premenopausal women with low-grade, early-stage disease, ovarian preservation could be considered.
  • Vaginal cuff removal is not advised, nor is there any benefit from excising parametrial tissue in the usual case.
  • Where obvious cervical stromal involvement is demonstrated preoperatively, a modified radical hysterectomy has been historically performed.
  • However, there is consensus that simple hysterectomy with free margins together with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy may be sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recommended standard surgical procedure in stage 1 endometrial cancer is an extra-fascial total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
  • Adnexal removal is recommended even if the tubes and ovaries appear normal, as they may contain micro metastases.

 

 

Ref: Figo cancer report 2021
